revision.text:
{{Redirect|Alien 2|the official sequel to the film ''Alien''|Aliens (film)|the 1987 videogame|Aliens: Alien 2}} {{refimprove|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox film |name = Alien 2: On Earth |image = Alien 2 - Sulla terra poster.jpg |caption = Italian theatrical poster |writer = Ciro Ippolito |starring = [[Belinda Mayne]]
Mark Bodin
Roberto Barrese
Benny Aldrich
[[Michele Soavi]]
Judy Perrin
Don Parkinson
Claudio Falanga |director = [[Ciro Ippolito]] (as Sam Cromwell)
Biagio Proietti (uncredited) |producer = Ciro Ippolito
Angiolo Stella |distributor = [[Cinema Shares International Distribution]] (1980, USA)
Fiesta Films (1981, Canada) |released = {{Film date|1980|04|11|Italy|df=y}} |runtime = 92 minutes |country = Italy
United States |language = English
Italian |budget = |music = [[Guido De Angelis]], [[Maurizio De Angelis]] (as The Oliver Onions) |followed by = }} '''''Alien 2: On Earth''''', also known as '''''Alien Terror''''', is a 1980 Italian-American science fiction horror film, written and directed by [[Ciro Ippolito]] before the [[trademark]] ''Alien'' was registered. It was released following the success of the 1979 film ''[[Alien (film)|Alien]]'' as an [[unofficial sequel]], albeit having little connection to the film. The film features a score by [[Guido De Angelis]] and [[Maurizio De Angelis]], performed by the composers under the [[pseudonym]] Oliver Onions. {{cn|date=September 2014}} The film co-starred a young [[Michele Soavi]], years before he became a famed Italian horror film director in his own right, and a cameo appearance by Ciro Ippolito himself (in the role of "Joe"). It was filmed in [[California]], the [[Cinecittà]] studios in Rome, and in the [[Castellana Caves]]. ==Plot== As the world awaits the return of [[Alien (film)|a crew of astronauts from a deep space mission]], a young woman named Thelma Joyce appears on a television talk show to discuss caves. Soon after her interview begins, Thelma has a horrible psychic vision. After the spacecraft returns to Earth missing its occupants, a girl on a beach discovers a weird, blue, pulsating rock. Her mother soon finds her with her face ripped off. Thelma and her husband Roy meet up with their friends for a trip to explore a cave. The group stops at a roadside café to buy food and change into their caving gear. Thelma's friend Burt discovers a blue rock that he decides to keep in his pack. The group arrives at the cave, and quickly rappels to the bottom to set up camp for the night. Before falling asleep, Thelma tells Roy that she feels that something horrible is about to happen, but Roy calms her down. The next day, Thelma's friend Jill discovers the blue rock that Burt found appears to be pulsating. The rock opens up and a creature attacks her face. Thelma witnesses the attack and panics. Roy calms her down, then decides to go find Jill's body. Roy rappels down into a hole and finds Jill, alive and with her face intact. The rest of the group rappels down the hole as well and they strap Jill to a lifter so that she may be lifted out of the hole. Jill is set aside by herself, still unconscious. While the group prepares to climb out of the hole, a creature erupts from Jill's face and attacks Phil's neck. Phil is dragged upside down as the creature slices his neck repeatedly until his head falls off. The group retreats though they are forced to initially go back to retrieve their equipment. The group splits up into teams to search for a way out, but to no avail. During the search Thelma reflects on what is happening and wonders if the disappearance of the astronauts is connected. Maurine stumbles upon a group of aliens who kill her and Burt who tries to save her. Roy hurts his ankle and is forced to sit and rest. Cliff opts to go and locate Burt and Maurine while the others rest. Thelma telepathically warns Cliff of a nearby alien after their radio goes dead, though Cliff is killed by the alien. Thelma and the others find Cliff who is actually an alien in disguise. Thelma uses her abilities to explode the imposter's head revealing the alien. The alien attacks the other member of the group while Thelma and Roy outrun the alien and escape the caves. On their way back to the city, they discover a police car, but no police officers are in sight. They stop at the roadside café again, but no one is there. Roy tries to call for help on a payphone, but no operator is available. They get back into the car and continue to drive to the city. Thelma and Roy finally get back to the city, but strangely, they cannot find anyone. They stop at the bowling alley, only to find that it is also empty. Roy goes to the back, only to be killed by an alien waiting there. The alien chases Thelma through the bowling alley, until she hits it in the head and leaves. Thelma runs through the empty city streets, calling for help but getting no answer. She finally stops yelling and sits down in an intersection. Suddenly, text shoots at the screen, warning the audience "You may be next!", implying that the aliens have taken over Earth. ==Cast== *[[Belinda Mayne]] as Thelma Joyce *[[Mark Bodin]] as Roy *[[Benedetta Fantoli]] as Maurine *[[Michele Soavi]] as Cliff *[[Benny Aldrich]] as Burt *[[Judy Perrin]] as Jill *[[Donald Hodson]] as Mr. Raymond *[[Ciro Ippolito]] as Joe ==Release== The film was released theatrically in Italy on April 11, 1980 as ''Alien 2: Sulla Terra'' ('"Alien 2: On Earth") and in [[West Germany]] on March 19, 1982 as ''Alien, die Saat des Grauens kehrt zurück'' ("Alien, the Seed of Horror Returns"). The [[English language|English]]-dubbed version was released theatrically in a limited way by Cinema Shares International Distribution (which distributed films such as ''[[Creature from Black Lake]]'', ''[[Godzilla vs. Mechagodzilla]]'' and ''[[The Pod People]]'').https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2011/03/22/hereafter-skyline-and-other-blu-ray-releases-of-the-week-032211/?mod=WSJBlog On March 22, 2011, Midnight Legacy re-released the English-dubbed version of the film on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray]] in the United States under its original title, ''Alien 2: On Earth'', in a 30,000 copy pressing. The re-release includes fully remastered picture and audio, although during the process, it was noted that some of the audio was missing and it had to be mixed from a variety of sources. This version of the film was believed to be longer than any other version, but a prior Italian television version contained additional scenes not present in the Midnight Legacy version. Midnight Legacy's release contains special effects outtakes and a Dutch trailer. ==Critical reception== {{expand section|date=September 2015}} Adam Tyner of ''[[DVD Talk]]'' wrote, "James Cameron once summed up his followup to Alien as 'forty miles of bad road'. Alien 2, meanwhile, is 'eighty-four minutes of bad, period'."{{cite web | url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/47613/alien-2-on-earth/ | title=Alien 2 | author=Adam Tyner | publisher=[[DVD Talk]] | accessdate=2011-03-24}} Daryl Loomis of ''[[DVD Verdict]]'' said, "Some people will say that Alien 2: On Earth is a blatant ripoff and some will say that it's a terrible movie. All of those people are right, but given my track record, nobody should be surprised that I love it."{{cite web |url=http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/alien2bluray.php |title=Alien 2 |author=Daryl Loomis |publisher=[[DVD Verdict]] |accessdate=2011-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110325072917/http://www.dvdverdict.com/reviews/alien2bluray.php |archivedate=2011-03-25 }} ==See also== {{Portal|Horror|Science fiction|Italy}} * ''[[Aliens (film)|Aliens]]'' * ''[[The Blob (1988 film)|The Blob]]'' * ''[[The Cave (film)|The Cave]]'' * ''[[Contamination (film)|Contamination]]'' * ''[[The Descent]]'' * ''[[Galaxy of Terror]]'' * ''[[Inseminoid]]'' * ''[[Parasite (film)|Parasite]] * ''[[The Thing (1982 film)|The Thing]]'' * ''[[Zombi 2]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|78749}} *{{amg title|532542}} {{Alien}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alien 2 (Italian Film)}} [[Category:1980 films]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:1980 horror films]] [[Category:1980s science fiction films]] [[Category:1980s science fiction horror films]] [[Category:Films about extraterrestrial life]] [[Category:Films set in the 1970s]] [[Category:1980s monster movies]] [[Category:Splatter films]] [[Category:American science fiction horror films]] [[Category:American monster movies]] [[Category:Italian science fiction films]] [[Category:Italian horror films]] [[Category:Italian-language films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Films scored by Guido & Maurizio De Angelis]] [[Category:Films shot in California]] [[Category:Unofficial sequel films]]

{{Use Australian English|date=October 2012}} {{Infobox film | name = Bad Bush | image = Bad Bush.jpg | caption = | director = [[Samuel Genocchio]] | producer = Samuel Genocchio | writer = Samuel Genocchio | starring = [[Chris Sadrinna]]
[[Jeremy Lindsay Taylor]]
[[Viva Bianca]] | music = [[Veren Grigorov]] | cinematography = [[Paul Howard (cinematographer)|Paul Howard]] | editing = [[Andreas Gruber]] | distributor = | released = {{Film date|df=yes|2009|5|7|Australia}} | runtime = 82 minutes | country = Australia | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Bad Bush''''' is a 2009 Australian [[Thriller (genre)|psychological thriller]] film. Starring [[Chris Sadrinna]] from television soap ''[[Home and Away]]'' and [[Jeremy Lindsay Taylor]] from ''[[Sea Patrol (TV series)|Sea Patrol]]'' and featuring [[Viva Bianca]] from ''[[Spartacus: Blood and Sand]]'' in her debut feature film, the film is based on the real-life story centred on a young woman with her baby alone with a crazed man on a property. The film was mostly made at [[Mangrove Mountain]] and [[Somersby, New South Wales|Somersby]] on the Central Coast, New South Wales. Appropximately 100 students from The Entrance High School worked on the film behind the scenes. ''Bad Bush'' premièred at the Avoca Beach Picture Theatre on 7 May 2009. ==Box office== ''Bad Bush'' grossed $8,961 at the box office in Australia.[http://film.vic.gov.au/resources/documents/AA4_Aust_Box_office_report.pdf ''Film Victoria - Australian Films at the Australian Box Office''] ==References== {{cite news |first= |last= |title= Soap to psycho|work= The Newcastle Herald |publisher= John Fairfax Holdings Limited|date= 7 May 2009}} {{cite news |first= Richard |last= Noone|title= Desirable location -- Coast lures filmmakers|work= Daily Telegraph|publisher=News Ltd |date= 31 March 2009}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1447944}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} [[Category:2009 films]] [[Category:Australian films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Australian independent films]] {{2000s-Australia-film-stub}}

{{good article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Bohemia Interactive a.s. | logo = Logo-bohemia-black.png | caption = | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | foundation = {{Start date and age|1999||}} | location = [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]] | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|Marek Španěl {{small|([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])}}|Slavomír Pavlíček {{small|([[Chief financial officer|CFO]])}}|Jarek Kolář {{small|([[Development Director]])}}}} | industry = [[Video game industry|Computer and video games]]
[[Interactive entertainment]] | products = [[Video games]] | owner = | revenue = {{increase}} {{CZK|796.1 million|link=yes}} (2016){{cite web|url=https://or.justice.cz/ias/ui/vypis-sl-firma?subjektId=510229|title=Veřejný rejstřík a Sbírka listin|website=Justice.cz|accessdate=September 24, 2018|date=December 31, 2016}} | operating_income = {{decrease}} {{CZK|500.1 million}} (2016) | equity = {{decrease}} {{CZK|471.9 million}} (2016) | num_employees = 346{{cite web|last1=Smutný|first1=Aleš|title=Bohemia Interactive spouští Incubator – nabízí zdarma prototypy her, aby otestovala jejich potenciál – Games.cz|url=http://games.tiscali.cz/oznameni/bohemia-interactive-spousti-incubator-nabizi-zdarma-prototypy-her-aby-otestovala-jejich-potencial-288199|website=Games.cz|accessdate=2 November 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161104042925/http://games.tiscali.cz/oznameni/bohemia-interactive-spousti-incubator-nabizi-zdarma-prototypy-her-aby-otestovala-jejich-potencial-288199|archivedate=4 November 2016|df=dmy-all}} | num_employees_year = 2018 | founders = {{Unbulleted list|Marek Španěl|Ondřej Španěl|Slavomír Pavlíček}} | parent = | divisions = | subsid = [[Altar Games]]
[[Black Element Software]]
[[Centauri Production]] | homepage = {{URL|https://www.bohemia.net/}} }} '''Bohemia Interactive''' is a [[video game development]] studio and [[video game publisher|publisher]], based in [[Prague]], [[Czech Republic]]. The company focuses on creating military [[simulation game]]s such as ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis]]'' and the ''[[ARMA (series)|ARMA]]'' series. It was also known for working on a game conversion of the ''[[DayZ (video game)|DayZ]]'' [[mod (video gaming)|mod]] created for ''[[ARMA 2]]''. Founded by Marek Španěl in 1999, the studio released its first game in 2001, a military shooter titled ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis]]'', which received critical acclaim and brought recognition for the studio. Following ''Operation Flashpoint'' was a series of downturns, such as [[port]]ing the game to [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]], which led to financial losses and the development of a sequel later abandoned by the publisher [[Codemasters]]. The studio fell into financial troubles until the [[United States Marine Corps]] employed the studio to create simulation games to train soldiers. A new division called [[Bohemia Interactive Simulations]] was created, and later spun off and become a standalone business entity. Following Codemasters' decision of not supporting the studio, Bohemia Interactive decided to develop a [[spiritual successor]] to ''Cold War Crisis'' titled ''[[ARMA: Armed Assault]]''. It was both a critical and financial success, spawning a number of sequels. Smaller projects such as ''[[Take On Helicopters]]'' were also released. In 2012, [[Dean Hall (game designer)|Dean Hall]] produced ''[[DayZ (mod)|DayZ]]'' a mod for ''[[ARMA 2]]'', that prompted the studio to develop a [[DayZ (video game)|standalone game]]. The same year saw the arrest of two employees of Bohemia, who were charged with [[espionage]] by Greece and jailed for 129 days. This event had significantly lowered team morale and forced the team to rename the ''[[ARMA 3]]''{{'}}s setting to a fictional one. The company is working on several new projects, including making a survival game named ''Vigor'', preparing ''DayZ'' for an eventual full release and developing ''[[Ylands]]'', a [[sandbox game]] which was part of Bohemia Incubator, a platform for Bohemia Interactive to release small, experimental projects ==History== ===Early history=== Bohemia Interactive was founded by Marek Španěl, Ondřej Španěl and Slavomír Pavlíček. He aspired to become a game developer in the 1980s, after his brother was convinced to buy a [[Texas Instruments TI-99/4A]] computer. Španěl first worked as a salesman for a game distribution company and made a 3D hovercraft simulator ''[[Gravon: Real Virtuality]]'' for [[Atari Falcon]] in 1995, which sold 400 copies only. He, along with his brother and another partner, decided to develop a game in 1997 using the money given by his former employers. He officially founded Bohemia Interactive in 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-04-29-bohemias-war-the-story-of-the-company-behind-arma-and-dayz|title=Bohemia's war: the story of the company behind Arma and DayZ|first=Robert|last=Purchese|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=April 30, 2014|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170712082859/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-04-29-bohemias-war-the-story-of-the-company-behind-arma-and-dayz|archivedate=12 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} The team initially wanted to develop a shooter named ''Rio Grande'', which was described by Španěl as "a [[3D computer graphics|3D]] clone of ''[[River Raid]]''". However, the team did not see the potential of the project and shifted their focus to make an [[open world]] game.{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2007/10/05/making-of-flashpoint/|title=Making Of: Operation Flashpoint|first=Kieron|last=Gillen|work=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]|date=October 5, 2007|accessdate=October 17, 2018}} It then became ''Poseidon'', which was a [[first-person shooter]] with a heavy focus on realism. At that time, the team expanded significantly, from having only one full-time programmer, to having 12 full-time employees by the end of the game's development. According to Španěl, the entire development team was very enthusiastic about the game and was focused on creating a game that they "wanted to play", thus opting not to study the works of another development team. ''Poseidon'' suffered from an extended development cycle of over three years, causing some of its technologies to become outdated. Original publisher [[Interactive Magic]] was sold in 1999 and another publisher which signed the project later wanted to abandon it. The frequent changes of publishers caused uncertainties regarding the game's funding. Despite these development issues, ''Poseidon'' was successfully released in June 2001 under the official title ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis]]'' by [[Codemasters]] to critical acclaim.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/operation-flashpoint-cold-war-crisis|title=Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis for PC reviews|work=[[Metacritic]]|publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|accessdate=August 9, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904090638/http://www.metacritic.com/game/pc/operation-flashpoint-cold-war-crisis|archivedate=4 September 2014|df=dmy-all}} It was shipped without any game-breaking [[Software bug|bugs]], and it became an international success, selling more than 500,000 copies in its first three months of release, as well as reaching a top position in retail sales chart across the world including US, UK, Germany and Australia. The team was satisfied with the game's release, with Španěl describing it as a dream coming true.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/131427/postmortem_bohemia_interactive_.php?page=3|title=Postmortem: Bohemia Interactive Studios' Operation Flashpoint|first=Markel|last=Spanel|date=December 19, 2001|accessdate=July 10, 2017|work=[[Gamasutra]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809131257/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/131427/postmortem_bohemia_interactive_.php?page=3|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Bohemia Interactive won Best Debut at the [[Game Developers Choice Awards]], defeating strong opponents including [[Remedy Entertainment]] (''[[Max Payne (video game)|Max Payne]]''). Following the release of ''Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis'', the team intended to continue updating the game with post-release content, develop a [[porting|port]] for the [[Xbox (console)|Xbox console]], and create a sequel. Projected to take only nine months to develop, the Xbox version also known as ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Elite]],'' was released in 2005, four years after the game's initial release.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/08/30/operation-flashpoint-elite-strikes|title=Operation Flashpoint: Elite Strikes|first=Wade|last=Steel|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 30, 2015|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809132911/http://www.ign.com/articles/2005/08/30/operation-flashpoint-elite-strikes|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} The reason for the long development cycle stemmed from the team's unfamiliarity with the console's structure. With the release of a new generation of hardware including [[Xbox 360|a new Xbox console]], ''Elite''{{'}}s release did not gain its audience's attention. Sales were lackluster and the development suffered a huge financial loss. In 2005 the company also founded the Independent Developers Association (IDEA) with [[Black Element Software]] and [[Altar Games]]. The organization aimed at supporting other independent game development studios with services including marketing support and negotiation with publishers.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/7567/IDEA_Independent_Developer_Association_Formed.php|title=IDEA Independent Developer Association Formed|first=Nick|last=Maragos|work=[[Gamasutra]]|date=December 19, 2005|accessdate=July 13, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110125030/http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/7567/IDEA_Independent_Developer_Association_Formed.php|archivedate=10 November 2011|df=dmy-all}} The team started developing a sequel to ''Operation Flashpoint'', codenamed ''Game 2'', after they canceled their [[open world]] [[wild west|Western-themed]] project, which was described as "''Flashpoint'' in Western" by Španěl. The team had lots of ambition for ''Game 2'' and hoped that it would become a perfect game, thus the team began spending an excessive amount of time on small details, from doing [[3D scanning]] of real-life weapons to modeling the player character's eyeball. However, in doing so some basics were neglected by the team, and many goals remained unattained due to the team's skill and technology status. As a result, the team constantly missed the deadlines set by publisher Codemasters. Codemasters was dissatisfied with the team's work and began looking for outside help. Bohemia disagreed with the search for outside assistance, and the two studio decided to part way with each other. With Codemasters no longer supporting the studio financially, Bohemia entered a series of financial troubles. In addition, Codemasters retained the rights to ''Operation Flashpoint'' preventing Bohemia from using the title in the future. ===''ARMA'' series=== In the early 2000s, the [[US Army]] began using a [[mod (video gaming)|mod]] of the first ''Operation Flashpoint'', named ''[[DARWARS|DARWARS Ambush!]]'', to train soldiers. In financial distress, Bohemia capitalized on its use and made a small sum of money, saving the company from falling into immediate bankruptcy. Bohemia also set up a new division called [[Bohemia Interactive Simulations]], specializing in creating military simulation games with its ''Virtual Battle Space'' titles for armies around the world to use. Meanwhile, the main studio, realizing that they should release a game as soon as possible, decided to rework on ''Elite''{{'}} engine and make a spiritual successor to ''Cold War Crisis'' called ''Armored Assault'', later renamed ''[[ARMA: Armed Assault]]''. According to Španěl, the team hated the title. Bohemia decided to self-publish the game, and launched in an [[early access]] form. The game received high critical praise and great sales, sufficient to save the company. {{quotebox|quote="We can't stop [[Codemasters]] from releasing a game using the words 'Operation Flashpoint'. But it is not right to promote this game as the ‘official sequel to the multi-award winning ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis]]'' or the ‘return' of Bohemia Interactive's ‘genre-defining military conflict simulator.' The awards were given for the game created by Bohemia Interactive – not to a name."|source = — Marek Španěl on the promotion of ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising]]''|width=25%}} The development of a sequel to ''ARMA'' commenced afterward. The team decided to reuse some of its assets of ''Game 2'' for ''[[ARMA 2]]'', and did not hold unrealistic ambitions for the game. A [[Xbox 360]] version was planned but was later scrapped after the team thought that its power was inferior to that of [[personal computer]]s. During this period, Codemasters announced ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising]]'', a game falling into competition with Bohemia's own ''ARMA'' titles, as it was marketed as the true successor to ''Cold War Crisis''.{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2009/02/27/bohemia-theres-only-one-real-flashpoint-sequel/|title=Bohemia: There’s Only One Real Flashpoint Sequel|first=Kieron|last=Gillen|date=February 27, 2009|accessdate=July 10, 2017|work=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809051737/https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2009/02/27/bohemia-theres-only-one-real-flashpoint-sequel/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Španěl was not happy with how ''Dragon Rising'' is being marketed as a return to the ''Operation Flashpoint'' series despite being created without the involvement of Bohemia.{{cite web|url=http://kotaku.com/5161328/operation-flashpoint-development-tensions-boil-over|title=Operation Flashpoint Development Tensions Boil Over|first=Luke|last=Plunkett|date=February 27, 2009|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[Kotaku]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809041736/http://kotaku.com/5161328/operation-flashpoint-development-tensions-boil-over|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} The team became anxious, but found relief after viewing gameplay footage ''Dragon Rising''{{'}}, which they considered to be subpar and "[did] not come even close to what they promised". ''ARMA 2'' was released in mid-2009 to high critical praise and high sales. The development team soon began work on an expansion titled ''[[ARMA 2: Operation Arrowhead|Operation Arrowhead]]'', though Codemasters took legal actions to force Bohemia to change its name due to its similarity with ''Operation Flashpoint''. In early 2010s, the company continued to develop expansions for ''ARMA 2'', and released smaller titles such as ''[[Take On Helicopters]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/exclusive-interview-bohemia-interactive-talks-take-on-helicopters/|title=Exclusive interview – Bohemia Interactive talks Take On Helicopters|first=Evan|last=Lahti|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=March 31, 2011|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809042919/http://www.pcgamer.com/exclusive-interview-bohemia-interactive-talks-take-on-helicopters/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Following the release of ''Operation Arrowhead'', the company started development of a new ''ARMA'' game, this time set in the future. The game was titled ''Arma Futura'', in which players fight aliens, and its direction once shifting to [[role-playing game|role-playing]]. All of these futuristic elements were later scrapped, and were remade into a more realistic setting. The title eventually became ''[[ARMA 3]]''. The Greek media reported in 2012 that two Czechs were arrested on the Greek island [[Lemnos]], the setting for ''ARMA III'' after being charged with espionage. This was later confirmed to be Martin Pezlar and Ivan Buchta, both of them employees at Bohemia Interactive. The main reason for their charge is that they took photos of military installations, which under Greek law threatened their [[national security]].{{cite web|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/bohemia-interactive-tells-the-story-of-arma-and-dayz|title=Bohemia Interactive Tells the Story of Arma and DayZ|first=Pete|last=Davison|work=USgamer|date=April 30, 2014|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809130734/http://www.usgamer.net/articles/bohemia-interactive-tells-the-story-of-arma-and-dayz|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Charges were refuted, and both of them insisted that they were traveling the island for entertainment only.{{cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2013/6/13/4425362/after-a-crazy-year-bohemia-is-hoping-for-a-much-much-quieter-life|title=After a crazy year, Bohemia is hoping for a much, much quieter life|first=Colin|last=Campbell|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=June 13, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809131240/https://www.polygon.com/2013/6/13/4425362/after-a-crazy-year-bohemia-is-hoping-for-a-much-much-quieter-life|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} If convicted, the duo faced a 20-year sentence. This soon became a diplomatic concern, with Czech President [[Václav Klaus]] urging the Greek President to solve this issue with "special attention". Bohemia also made efforts by motivating its ''ARMA'' communities to petition to pressure Greece for the pair's release. During this period of time, team morale dropped. ''[[Carrier Command: Gaea Mission]]'' was released by the studio, but according to Španěl, "nobody at the studio really cared" because their friends were stranded in a foreign jail. Regardless, Pezlar and Buchta were held in prison for 129 days until the Greek government allowed them to be released on bail.{{cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2013/2/8/3959776/arma-3-bohemia-interactive-prison-ivan-buchta|title=129 days in prison: A Bohemia developer speaks out about his detainment in Greece|first=Emily|last=Gera|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=February 8, 2013|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170701104923/https://www.polygon.com/2013/2/8/3959776/arma-3-bohemia-interactive-prison-ivan-buchta|archivedate=1 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} After this incident, the team decided to renamed ''ARMA 3''{{'}} setting from Lemnos to a fictional island called "Altis".{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2013/02/01/arma-3-now-set-on-island-of-altis/|title=Arma 3 now set on island of 'Altis'|first=JC|last=Fletcher|work=[[Engadget]]|date=February 2, 2013|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809131234/https://www.engadget.com/2013/02/01/arma-3-now-set-on-island-of-altis/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} ''Arma III'' was eventually released in August 2013 to positive critical reviews. Two mobile ''ARMA'' games, ''[[ARMA Tactics]]'' and ''ARMA Mobile Ops'', were released in 2013 and 2016 respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-01-30-arma-dev-announces-turn-based-strategy-spinoff-arma-tactics|title=ArmA dev announces turn-based strategy spin-off Arma Tactics|first=Tom|last=Phillips|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=January 30, 2013|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160316041552/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2013-01-30-arma-dev-announces-turn-based-strategy-spinoff-arma-tactics|archivedate=16 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/Android/Arma+Mobile+Ops/news.asp?c=70361|title=Even Bohemia is getting in the Clash of Clans-like market with Arma Mobile Ops, soft launched|first=Clement|last=Renaudin|work=[[Pocket Gamer]]|date=June 9, 2016|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809131307/http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/Android/Arma+Mobile+Ops/news.asp?c=70361|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} In January 2013 the investment copmany Riverside Co. bought Bohemia Interactive Simulations. While both companies share the engine technology due to the shared past they are now completely separate entities.{{cite news |last1=Ribbens |first1=Megan |title=N.Y. private-equity firm buys Orlando-based Bohemia Interactive Simulations Inc. |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/orlando/morning_call/2013/01/ny-private-equity-firm-buys.html |accessdate=24 September 2018 |work=Orlando Business Journal |date=January 10, 2013}} ===Current projects=== In 2012, [[Dean Hall (game designer)|Dean Hall]], an employee at Bohemia working on ''ARMA 3'', released a massively popular mod for ''Arma II'' named ''[[DayZ (mod)|DayZ]]'', which includes [[zombie]]s as the game's main enemies.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/08/01/how-dayz-came-to-life|title=How DayZ Came To Life|first=Colin|last=Campbell|work=[[IGN]]|date=August 1, 2012|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120804013610/http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/08/01/how-dayz-came-to-life|archivedate=4 August 2012|df=dmy-all}} Its popularity led to a resurgence in ''ARMA 2''{{'}}s sales, with registered players count being raised from 500,000 to one million. Impressed with the success of ''DayZ'', Bohemia appointed Hall to fully capitalize on it by leading the development of a [[DayZ (video game)|standalone ''DayZ'' video game]], which ensured that he would not be limited by the restraints of ''Arma 2''. While the main goal is to transit the mod into an entirely new game, the team also intended to add more content such as base-building and improved crafting.{{cite web|url=https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2012/08/from-mod-to-game-how-dayz-will-evolve-as-a-standalone-release/|title=From mod to game: How DayZ will evolve as a standalone release|first=Kyle|last=Orland|work=[[Ars Technica]]|date=August 8, 2012|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170713204240/https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2012/08/from-mod-to-game-how-dayz-will-evolve-as-a-standalone-release/|archivedate=13 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} Hall eventually left Bohemia in 2014,{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-02-24-dean-hall-to-leave-bohemia-and-step-down-as-leader-of-dayz|title=Dean Hall to leave Bohemia and step down as leader of DayZ|first=Robert|last=Purchese|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=February 24, 2014|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170713133701/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2014-02-24-dean-hall-to-leave-bohemia-and-step-down-as-leader-of-dayz|archivedate=13 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} and the game remained in early access more than four years after its release in December 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.destructoid.com/-update-after-nearly-four-years-of-early-access-dayz-is-entering-beta-434110.phtml|title=(Update) After nearly four years of Early Access, DayZ is entering beta|work=[[Destructoid]]|first=Brett|last=Makedonski|date=May 2, 2017|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170513065110/https://www.destructoid.com/-update-after-nearly-four-years-of-early-access-dayz-is-entering-beta-434110.phtml|archivedate=13 May 2017|df=dmy-all}} In November 2016, the company announced Bohemia Incubator, a platform for the development of experimental games. According to Bohemia Interactive, the incubator aimed at testing designs and concepts and getting the community involved in game development, as well as being the guidance of Bohemia's other technologies including its Enfusion engine and supporting services. Two titles were announced as part of the incubator.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/bohemia-interactive-just-announced-two-new-projects/|title=Bohemia Interactive just announced two new projects|first=Evan|last=Lahti|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=November 1, 2016|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170603205704/http://www.pcgamer.com/bohemia-interactive-just-announced-two-new-projects/|archivedate=3 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} This includes ''[[Ylands]]'', a sandbox game, and ''[[Argo (video game)|Argo]]'', a [[free-to-play]] shooter without [[microtransaction]]s released in June 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/arma-devs-free-new-game-launches-next-month-wont-h/1100-6450451/|title=Arma Dev's Free New Game Launches Next Month, Won't Have Microtransactions|first=Alex|last=Newhouse|work=[[GameSpot]]|date=June 2, 2017|accessdate=July 10, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170626205601/https://www.gamespot.com/articles/arma-devs-free-new-game-launches-next-month-wont-h/1100-6450451/|archivedate=26 June 2017|df=dmy-all}} The company is also working on ''Vigor'', a [[survival game]] powered by [[Unreal Engine]] for the [[Xbox One]].{{cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/e3/2018/6/11/17437954/vigor-xbox-one-bohemia-interactive-arma-dayz|title=Vigor is a new survival game from the studio behind Arma and DayZ|first=Charlie|last=Hall|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=June 11, 2018|accessdate=October 17, 2018}} ==Philosophy== [[File:Alabino05042017-40.jpg|thumb|right|Bohemia Interactive announced their acquisition of a [[T-72]] tank in October 2015.]] Bohemia Interactive prides themselves on open communication with players.{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2015/10/15/whats-next-for-arma-3/|title=What’s next for Arma 3?|first=Brenna|last=Hillier|work=[[VG 247]]|date=October 15, 2015|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809052449/https://www.vg247.com/2015/10/15/whats-next-for-arma-3/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} The company laid out road maps in an effort to offer details on some of their post-release content, such as in the case of ''ARMA 3'' and ''DayZ''.{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/11/27/dayzs-2015-road-map-price-increase/|title=DayZ’s 2015 Dev Road Map Begins With A Price Increase|first=Graham|last=Smith|date=November 27, 2014|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809051758/https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2014/11/27/dayzs-2015-road-map-price-increase/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} The company also sometimes let players to help out with game design process. It invited players to the Czech studio to help with the design of the first ''Operation Flashpoint'', and released several titles via [[early access]], a way in which early build of a game is released for the community to test and play.{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/08/13/the-good-and-bad-of-early-access-from-arma-3-dev/|title=The good and bad of early access from Arma 3 dev|first=Jessica|last=Conduit|work=[[Engadget]]|date=August 13, 2014|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809040910/https://www.engadget.com/2014/08/13/the-good-and-bad-of-early-access-from-arma-3-dev/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Many of Bohemia Interactive games are moddable, a focus since the release of the ''ARMA: Armed Assault''. The company awarded players who create [[user-generated content]] with their games in 2009 during the BIS Community Awards{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2010/02/15/bis-community-awards-winners/#more-25442|title=BIS Community Awards Winners|first=Jim|last=Rossignol|work=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]|date=February 15, 2010|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809051729/https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2010/02/15/bis-community-awards-winners/#more-25442|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} and announced a modding competition called "Make ''Arma'' Not War", in which modders must create mods that shift ''ARMA''{{'s}} focus from war into anything else.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/make-arma-not-war-modding-competition-launched-with-680000-up-for-grabs/|title="Make Arma Not War" modding competition launched with $680,000 up for grabs|first=Evan|last=Lathi|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=December 5, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809044437/http://www.pcgamer.com/make-arma-not-war-modding-competition-launched-with-680000-up-for-grabs/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Bohemia Interactive also took a stance against [[Copyright infringement|pirating]] with their DEGRADE technology, which would automatically create technical issues to pirated copies.{{cite web|url=http://www.pcgamer.com/interview-bohemia-interactives-ceo-on-fighting-piracy-creative-drm/|title=Interview: Bohemia Interactive's CEO on fighting piracy, creative DRM|first=Nathan|last=Grayson|work=[[PC Gamer]]|date=November 17, 2011|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170705083737/http://www.pcgamer.com/interview-bohemia-interactives-ceo-on-fighting-piracy-creative-drm/|archivedate=5 July 2017|df=dmy-all}} For instance, in ''Take On Heliciopters'', pirated copies' visuals would be extremely blurry, whereas copies bought legitimately would not suffer from the same issue.{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-11-04-take-on-helicopters-includes-smart-anti-piracy-trick|title=Take On Helicopters hides smart anti-piracy tech|first=Fred|last=Dutton|work=[[Eurogamer]]|date=November 4, 2011|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809051609/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2011-11-04-take-on-helicopters-includes-smart-anti-piracy-trick|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} The team also bought a [[T-72]] tank in order to express gratitude, stating: "A massive tanks goes out to everyone who has supported the studio and its games throughout the past 16 years".{{cite web|url=http://niero.dev.destructoid.com/arma-dayz-developer-bought-a-tank-315915.phtml|title=Arma, DayZ developer bought a tank|first=Steven|last=Hanson|work=[[Destructoid]]|date=October 16, 2015|accessdate=July 12, 2017}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{Cite web|url=https://www.bistudio.com/blog/bohemia-interactive-latest-acquisition-t72-main-battle-tank|title=Bohemia Interactive's Latest Acquisition: T-72 Main Battle Tank {{!}} Blog {{!}} Bohemia Interactive|website=Bohemia Interactive|language=en|access-date=2017-08-24|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824133954/https://www.bistudio.com/blog/bohemia-interactive-latest-acquisition-t72-main-battle-tank|archivedate=24 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} According to Joris-Jan van ‘t Land, the project lead for ''ARMA 3'', Bohemia Interactive gives their employees a lot of freedom and autonomy. Employees can brainstorm ideas and exchange with each other, and some of these ideas may be implemented as official releases, shown through one of ''ARMA 3''{{'}}s [[downloadable content]]s, ''Zeus''.{{cite web|url=https://www.pcper.com/reviews/Editorial/Interview-Bohemia-Interactive-ArmA-3-Developer-Expansion-Optimization-Roadmap|title=Interview with Bohemia Interactive, ArmA 3 Developer: Expansion, Optimization, Roadmap|first=Ryan|last=Shrout|work=PC Perspective|date=February 24, 2015|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160909072753/http://www.pcper.com/reviews/Editorial/Interview-Bohemia-Interactive-ArmA-3-Developer-Expansion-Optimization-Roadmap|archivedate=9 September 2016|df=dmy-all}} Bohemia Interactive also had a close relationship with [[International Committee of the Red Cross]], in which they partnered together for a special award named Health Care in Danger Special Award at the Make Arma Not War competition, and Bohemia also promised to follow some of Red Cross' suggestions on how video games should handle [[war crime]]s.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2013/oct/03/red-cross-players-accountable-war-crimes|title=Should gamers be accountable for in-game war crimes?|first=Keith|last=Stuart|date=October 3, 2013|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[The Guardian]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117122849/https://www.theguardian.com/technology/gamesblog/2013/oct/03/red-cross-players-accountable-war-crimes|archivedate=17 November 2017|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=https://www.polygon.com/2014/5/28/5757718/arma-3-red-cross-international-committee-bohemia-interactive-make-arma-not-war|title=Arma 3 wants to send you into a war zone with the Red Cross|first=Samit|last=Sarker|work=[[Polygon (website)|Polygon]]|date=May 28, 2014|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171117174521/https://www.polygon.com/2014/5/28/5757718/arma-3-red-cross-international-committee-bohemia-interactive-make-arma-not-war|archivedate=17 November 2017|df=dmy-all}} ==Developed games== Bohemia Interactive specialized in making [[simulation]] games with a focus on realism. They had created the military simulation game ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis]]'' as their debut game, and followed it with an expansion called ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Resistance]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/32781-suicide-is-painless-stop-worrying-and-love-the-bomb-review|title=Suicide Is Painless – Stop Worrying And Love The Bomb|date=August 12, 2012|accessdate=July 12, 2017|work=[[Game Revolution]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809132406/http://www.gamerevolution.com/review/32781-suicide-is-painless-stop-worrying-and-love-the-bomb-review|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} While Codemasters developed two ''Operation Flashpoint'' sequels, ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Dragon Rising]]'' and ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Red River]]'', the series was put on hiatus when Codemasters announced their plans to refocus on [[racing games]].{{cite web|url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2011-09-14-codemasters-to-close-guildford-studio|title=Codemasters to close Guildford studio|first=Rachel|last=Weber|work=Gameindustry.biz|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809133527/http://www.gamesindustry.biz/articles/2011-09-14-codemasters-to-close-guildford-studio|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} Meanwhile, Bohemia followed up their first game, ''Cold War Crisis'' with a [[spiritual successor]]{{cite web|url=http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/armed-assault/782075p1.html|title=Armed Assault: Combat Operations|first=Kuo|last=Li|work=[[GameSpy]]|date=April 19, 2007|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008193346/http://pc.gamespy.com/pc/armed-assault/782075p1.html|archivedate=8 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} called ''[[ARMA: Armed Assault]]'', which was followed up by two sequels, ''[[Arma 2]]'' and ''[[Arma 3]]'', both of which have been critically acclaimed. The developer also had another simulation franchise called ''Take On'', which includes ''[[Take On Helicopters]]'', which allows players to play as a helicopter pilot, and ''[[Take On Mars]]'', in which players explore [[Mars]].{{cite web|url=https://www.vg247.com/2017/02/13/take-on-mars-lands-on-the-steam-store-after-three-years-in-early-access/|title=Take on Mars lands on the Steam Store after three years in Early Access|first=Sharif|last=Arid|work=[[VG 247]]|date=February 13, 2017|accessdate=July 12, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809133709/https://www.vg247.com/2017/02/13/take-on-mars-lands-on-the-steam-store-after-three-years-in-early-access/|archivedate=9 August 2017|df=dmy-all}} However, both titles are smaller in scope when compared with the ''ARMA'' franchise. {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Title !! System |- | 2001 | ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Cold War Crisis]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Linux]] |- | 2002 | ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Resistance]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2005 | ''[[Operation Flashpoint: Elite]]'' | [[Xbox (console)|Xbox]] |- | 2006 | ''[[ARMA: Armed Assault]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2007 | ''[[ARMA: Queen's Gambit]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2009 | ''[[Arma 2]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2010 | ''[[ARMA 2: Operation Arrowhead|Arma 2: Operation Arrowhead]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2011 | ''[[Take On Helicopters]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2012 | ''[[Carrier Command: Gaea Mission]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Xbox 360]] |- | rowspan="2"|2013 | ''[[ARMA Tactics|Arma Tactics]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]], [[Shield Portable]] |- | ''[[Arma 3]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2016 | ''Arma Mobile Ops'' | [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] |- | rowspan="3"|2017 | ''[[Take On Mars]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | ''Mini DayZ'' | [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]] |- | ''[[Argo (video game)|Argo]]'' | [[Microsoft Windows]] |- | 2018 | ''[[DayZ (video game)|DayZ]]'' (currently in BETA) | [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]] |- | rowspan="2"|TBA | ''[[Ylands]]'' (currently in early access) | [[Microsoft Windows]], [[PlayStation 4]], [[Xbox One]] |- | ''[[Vigor (video game)|Vigor]]'' (currently in early access) | [[Xbox One]] |} ==Sources== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{official website|https://www.bohemia.net/}} {{portal bar|Companies|Czech Republic|Video games}} {{Bohemia Interactive |state=expanded}} [[Category:Video game companies established in 1999]] [[Category:Video game companies of the Czech Republic]] [[Category:Video game development companies]]

revision.text:
{{about|the character from the Transformers franchise|the 2018 film |Bumblebee (film)}} {{multiple issues| {{in-universe|date=July 2014}} {{More citations needed|date=September 2010}} }} {{Transformers character | name = Bumblebee/Goldbug | japanname = Bumble/Goldback | image = Bumblebee_G1.jpg | caption = | affiliation = Autobot | subgroup = Minicars, Throttlebots, Pretenders, Action Masters, Go-Bots, Deluxe machines | function = [[Espionage]], Espionage Director, Spy, Scout | partner = [[Brawn (Transformers)|Brawn]], [[Optimus Prime]], [[Spike Witwicky]], [[Chip Chase#Humans|Chip Chase]], [[Pipes (Transformers)|Pipes]], [[Tailgate (Transformers)#Autobots|Tailgate]], [[Swerve (Transformers)|Swerve]], [[Warpath (Transformers)#Mini-Vehicles|Warpath]], [[Huffer (Transformers)|Huffer]], [[Cosmos (Transformers)|Cosmos]], [[Powerglide (Transformers)|Powerglide]], [[Gears (Transformers)|Gears]], [[Outback (Transformers)|Outback]] | rank = 7 | motto = "''The least likely can be the most dangerous.''" (Bumblebee)
"''To know others you must know yourself first.''" (Goldbug)
"''Data is power.''" (Classic) | alternatemodes = Cybertronian Car, [[Volkswagen Beetle]], [[Suzuki Swift]], muscle car | series = ''[[Transformers: Generation 1]]''
''[[Transformers: Generation 2]]''
''[[Transformers: Titanium]]''
''[[Transformers: Classic]]''
''[[Transformers: Attacktix]]''
''[[Transformers: Universe]]''
''[[Transformers: Alternity]]''
''[[Transformers: Reveal the Shield]]'' | engvoice = [[Dan Gilvezan]] | japanvoice = [[Yoku Shioya]] (Generation 1) [[Michitaka Kobayashi]] (The Headmasters) }} '''Bumblebee''' is a [[Character (arts)|fictional]] robot superhero character from the [[Transformers]] franchise. In most versions, Bumblebee is a small, yellow with black stripes [[Autobot]], with most of his alternative vehicle modes inspired by several generations of the [[Chevrolet]] American [[muscle car]]s – with the live-action film versions being a yellow [[Camaro]] with black racing stripes. The original vehicle-mode design was based on a classic European Type 1 [[Volkswagen Beetle]].{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagodefender.com/article-5370-movie-review-transformers-revenge-of-the-fallen-brings-incredible-visual-effects-plus-comic-relief.html |title=Movie Review: 'Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen' brings incredible visual effects plus comic relief |newspaper=[[The Chicago Defender]] |accessdate=September 8, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522204517/http://www.chicagodefender.com/article-5370-movie-review-transformers-revenge-of-the-fallen-brings-incredible-visual-effects-plus-comic-relief.html |archivedate=May 22, 2010 |df=}} The character is named after the [[Bumblebee]], a black-and-yellow striped [[bee]] which inspired his paint scheme. == Transformers: Generation 1 == Bumblebee (known as '''Abejorro''' in [[Mexico]], '''Bumble''' in [[Japan]], '''Moscardo''' in [[Portugal]], '''Űrdongó''' in [[Hungary]], '''Maggiolino''' in [[Italy]], '''Bourdon''' in [[France]]) is the "little brother" of the heroic or protagonistic Autobot faction and a [[mascot]], constantly striving to prove himself in the eyes of the other robots—especially his leader, [[Optimus Prime]]. This often causes him to take risks that put him in danger. Although a bit of a smart aleck, he is a capable and reliable messenger and spy, his small size allowing him to go places that his larger commanders cannot. He is highly fuel-efficient, has great visual acuity, is particularly adaptable to undersea environments and transforms into a Saturn yellow [[Volkswagen Beetle]]. He was later reconstructed into a stronger, more mature form as Goldbug. ===Reception=== At [[BotCon]] 2010, Hasbro named Bumblebee as one of the first five robot inductees in the Transformers Hall of Fame.{{cite web |url=http://www.hasbro.com/transformers/en_US/discover/movie-news/Hall-Of-Fame-robots.cfm |title=Transformers Hall of Fame Robots |website=Hasbro.com |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100705131942/http://www.hasbro.com/transformers/en_US/discover/movie-news/Hall-Of-Fame-robots.cfm |archive-date=July 5, 2010}} === Animated series === ====The Transformers==== Bumblebee holds the distinction of being the second character to appear on-screen in the original ''Transformers'' animated series, while on a mission to recover a small clutch of energy conductors with [[Wheeljack]], illustrating the energy crisis holding sway over their home planet of [[Cybertron]]. These two characters were often seen together in the first season and beginning of the second season, sometimes going on missions. Bumblebee is subsequently among the Transformers aboard [[Ark (Transformers)|the ''Ark'']] as it set off searching for new worlds and new energy sources, which crashed on Earth, causing the Transformers within to be trapped in stasis for four million years. Awakening in 1984, Bumblebee helps [[Ironhide]] quell a raging river and uses his small size to help the human Autobot ally [[Sparkplug (Transformers)|Sparkplug Witwicky]] plant explosives in the midst of a Decepticon mining operation. He later befriends Sparkplug's son [[Spike Witwicky|Spike]], but on their first adventure together they are both kidnapped by the Decepticons, and Bumblebees memory chip were altered as he unintentionally lured the other Autobots into a trap. Bumblebee recovered in time to help his fellow Autobots stop the Decepticons from sending Spike to Cybertron. After their first adventure, Bumblebee and Spike became best friends for life as they both realized that they make a good team. Bumblebee got injured with Spike inside from a battle with the Decepticons at a rocket base. While Bumblebee gets repaired by Ratchet, Spike's mind was transferred into Autobot X, a robot created by Sparkplug, while his real body was getting fixed at the hospital, due to his injuries from the battle being more severe then his were. When Spike left base as there was a side effect of the mind transfer, Bumblebee left afterwards to go look for his best friend but his radio transmitters weren't fixed yet. After finding Spike, Bumblebee tries to get his pal to come to his senses but failed when Spike believed that he was tricking him. Bumblebee sees the Decepticons arriving at their location but they didn't see him so he was able to hear Megatron tell lies to his best friend then left to go get Optimus and the rest of his Autobot friends for help, as they were helping with repairs at the rocket base they were battling at before. Bumblebee tells Optimus, after arriving at the rocket base, that Megatron is manipulating Spike and he's starting to believe him. Bumblebee was asks to lead the way of their location by Optimus, who feared that the Decepticons would find and take adventage of Spike messed up mind, so they can help their friend. After finding Spike, Bumblebee and Optimus tried talking some sense into him but it didn't work as they hoped it would but they were both relieved when he did when Sparkplug was endangered. After the Decepticons left, Bumblebee gave his best friend a high five when he returned to his real body when it got all fixed up. Bumblebee accompanies Spike and Sparkplug with [[Jazz (Transformers)|Jazz]] to test out his new speakers but decided to head to headquarters so wouldn't have to deal with his loud music. When Bumblebee return to headquarters he saw no one but Bluestreak there and that Telatran One was damaged then was dragged to the recharging chamber by Bluestreak, due to Megatron putting a personality destabilizer in their recharging chamber to turn all the Autobots evil. However, Bumblebee was saved when Jazz, Spike and Sparkplug arrived back just in time as Jazz knocked Bluestreak out for a while. After Sparkplug fixed Telatran One, Bumblebee, Jazz, Spike and Sparkplug became shocked when Telatran One tells them that Megatron turned their friends from good to evil. With Bumblebee and Jazz being the only ones who weren't affected from the personality destabilizer. Bumblebee decided to stop his comrades when he hears about Optimus Prime with Brawn and Prowl attacking an Air Force jet base with Spike accompanying him. Once they arrived, Bumblebee tried a few times to get through to Optimus but to no success. Bumblebee was relieved that his friends were free from the Decepticons control, after Sparkplug invented Attitude exchanger to counteract the personality destabilizer effects, except for Optimus. Bumblebee took the last one, as there was no other ones left, as he wanted to make one final attempted to get Optimus back to his senses. Bumblebee tells his friend/leader that he's not evil and he believes in him then encourages him to fight off Megatron's control also to not give in. Bumblebee quickly put the Attitude exchanger on Optimus, who heard his voice, leg which freed him from the Decepticons control. Bumblebee was given a hug by Optimus as a thank you for not giving up on him and for saving him. After stopping the Decepticons, Bumblebee was thanked again by Optimus, who also thanked everyone for their help, for what he did for him. Bumblebee with Spike gave Ratchet and Sparkplug tools as they them to fix the Air Force jets the Autobots destroyed while under Megatron's control. When the body of the deceased Optimus Prime is recovered from space by a pair of Transformer-hating human scientists who intend to use it to lure the Autobots into a trap, Bumblebee is part of the rescue team led by [[Rodimus Prime]] to recover it. Entering the lab, some of the Transformers are exposed to rage-inducing alien spores that could infect them with the Hate Plague, which causes them to run wild, and although Bumblebee avoids infection, he is seriously damaged by the infected rampaging [[Aerialbots|Superion]]. A member of the alien race called the [[Quintesson]]s subsequently repair and restore Optimus Prime to life, so he can stop the Hate Plague and repair Bumblebee. The little Autobot was so severely damaged, however, that he required an entire reconstruction and is rebuilt as a [[Throttlebot]]. In his new, shiny body, he comments that he has gone beyond just being plain old Bumblebee, and is now a "gold bug", prompting Optimus Prime to redub him '''Goldbug'''. Goldbug travels with Optimus Prime to the Decepticon planet of [[Chaar]] in order to secure a heat-resistant alloy that can protect him from the plague, only to be infected on the mission and later cured when Prime uses the power of the [[Matrix of Leadership]] to purge the plague. Goldbug also makes a brief appearance in the fourth and final season of the series, defending [[Autobot City]] and Cybertron against a massive Decepticon attack. Because of an animation error, Bumblebee appears in his Bumblebee incarnation during a wide shot in a celebration during the series' final episode. ====Transformers: The Headmasters==== In ''[[Transformers: The Headmasters]]'', Goldbug and the other Throttlebots were on Cybertron when [[Vector Sigma]] began to destabilize as a consequence of [[Optimus Prime]] releasing the Matrix's energy to cure the Hate Plague the previous year. The Decepticons soon invaded the planet in an attempt to take control of the computer, and Goldbug and the Throttlebots joined [[Dinobots]] [[Grimlock]] and [[Slag (Transformers)|Slag]] in holding the line against them. Unfortunately, they were knocked unconscious by the hypnotic power of the new Decepticon [[Headmaster (Transformers)|Headmaster]] [[Mindwipe (Transformers)|Mindwipe]], but they had managed to delay the Decepticons long enough for the Autobot Headmasters to arrive and take up the fight. The Throttlebots disappeared after this encounter, suggesting they might have been destroyed, but they eventually resurfaced months later as the Decepticons were carrying out their final plan to destroy the Earth. Goldbug and the Throttlebots teamed up with [[Fastlane (Transformers)|Fastlane]] and [[Cloudraker (Transformers)|Cloudraker]] to investigate the emergence of a "Death Tower" in [[Santiago]], [[Chile]], only to find [[Predaking]] there waiting for them. Naturally, the small 'bots were no match for the powerful combiner, but they fought bravely, clinging onto his limbs before being hurled aside. Luckily, the [[Autobot]] [[Targetmaster]]s arrived in time to bail them out and take Predaking down. This is also because of the budget cut that happened in the middle of the movie. ===Books=== ====Ballantine Books==== Bumblebee was featured in the 1985 [[Find Your Fate]] Junior books ''[[Dinobots Strike Back]]'' by [[Casey Todd]] and ''[[Battle Drive]]'' by [[Barbara Siegel]] and [[Scott Siegel]]. ====Kid Stuff Records & Tapes==== Bumblebee was featured in the 1985 audio and book adventure ''[[List of Transformers books#Satellite of Doom|Satellite of Doom]]'' publishing by [[Kid Stuff Records & Tapes]]. ====Modern Publishing==== Bumblebee was featured in the 1993 ''Transformers: Generation 2'' coloring book ''[[Decepticon Madness]]'' by [[Bud Simpson]].{{cite book |last=Simpson |first=Bud |isbn=1-56144-346-8 |title=Decepticon Madness |publisher=[[Modern Publishing]] |year=1993}} ===Comics=== Bumblebee has appeared in numerous comic books and related media printed by various publishers. ==== 3H Enterprises ==== Bumblebee appeared in the voice actor play performed at [[BotCon]] 2004, in which a device built by [[Rhinox]] to stop [[Unicron]] from pulling victims from other dimensions inadvertently transports an Autobot shuttle under Bumblebee's command into the middle of a battle between [[Rattrap (Transformers)|Rattrap]], [[Silverbolt (Beast Wars and Beast Machines)|Silverbolt]], and [[Waspinator]] and a team of Unicron's agents. Bumblebee's shuttle is able to scoop up Rattrap and company when their ship is destroyed. After saving more of Unicron's victims from the Decepticons, Bumblebee's team returns to their own time. ====Condor Verlag==== In a story called "By their Blasters you shall know them ...!" from ''[[Transformers Comic-Magazin]]'' issue #12 by German comic publisher [[Condor Verlag]] [[Optimus Prime]] instructs [[Backstreet (Transformers)|Backstreet]], Bumblebee and [[Ruckus (Transformers)|Ruckus]] on how to identify Autobots from Decepticons in battle using the Ark's computer. Pretender Bumblebee is one of those he displays to the Autobots.{{Cite comic |writer=Robert Mann |penciller= |inker= |story=By their Blasters you shall know them...! |title=Transformers Comic-Magazin |volume=1 |issue=12 |date=December 1990 | publisher=[[Condor Verlag]] |location=}} ==== Devil's Due Publishing ==== In [[Devil's Due Publishing|Devil's Due]]'s first ''G.I. Joe vs. The Transformers'' crossover, the evil terrorist organization [[Cobra Command|Cobra]] are the first to uncover the ''Ark'' and the Transformers slumbering within it, capturing and reformatting a large number of them to use them as war machines. Bumblebee and [[Wheeljack]] are able to avoid this fate, contact the team created to respond to the threat of Cobra, G.I. Joe, and help to free their fellow Autobots. Unlike most Autobots, who had new alternate modes, Bumblebee and Wheeljack had their original Generation 1 alternate modes in this series. In the second crossover, Bumblebee is among the Autobots sent back in time due to an accident with the spacebridge computer Teletran-3. As part of a small group transported to the 1970s, Bumblebee is reformatted as a small economy car (this time, resembling an [[AMC Pacer]]) before the teamed-up Joes and Cobras return all the Transformers to present-day Cybertron. Bumblebee takes center stage in the third crossover series, as he, Grimlock, [[Arcee]], and [[Perceptor]] are sent to Earth to aid G.I. Joe in removing the influence of Cybertronian technology on the planet. Sporting his original alternate mode again, he is shown to have something of a crush on Arcee. When Cobra attacks the base, the Autobots help repel the Cobra Battle Android Trooper armies. Journeying to Cybertron to stop [[Serpentor]], the mismatched group is ambushed first by Cannibalizers, then by Serpentor, [[Seacons|Piranacon]], [[Predacons|Predaking]] and the [[Stunticon]]s, with Bumblebee being badly injured as he runs right into Predaking's leg. He is then executed by Serpentor, who would later comment that Bumblebee's death is the only thing that ever really made him feel emotion. Despite the character being notoriously difficult to kill, it seems his death is permanent, as Serpentor comments that he felt something leave him, most likely his spark. A statue to his memory was seen in the final issue. His death would continue to have repercussions, as seen in the fourth series, in which Prime insists on journeying to Earth personally rather than expose any of his troops to the same fate. ==== Dreamwave Productions ==== When [[Dreamwave Productions]] introduced their re-imagined version of Generation 1 continuity for the 21st Century, Bumblebee was present for the Autobots' new adventures once again. ''The War Within'', set in Cybertron's past, chronicled Bumblebee's early adventures in the Battle of Altihex and the defense of Iacon in the face of an attack by [[Shockwave (Transformers)|Shockwave]]. When Optimus Prime and [[Megatron]] vanish in an early spacebridge experiment, causing the Autobots and Decepticons to splinter into smaller factions, Bumblebee remains with the Autobots under [[Prowl (Transformers)|Prowl]]'s command. As usual, Bumblebee is among the Transformers trapped in stasis aboard the crashed ''Ark'' who are reactivated on Earth in 1984. Although not depicted in fiction, the general events of the television series pilot seemed to take place in the Dreamwave continuity - with Bumblebee meeting and befriending [[Witwicky family#Spike Witwicky|Spike Witwicky]]. ==== Fun Publications ==== Classic Bumblebee was featured on the cover of ''Transformers Club Magazine'' #14. In a possible future chronicled in the exclusive comic book available at BotCon 2005, Bumblebee featured as the espionage director of the Autobots. Having been on the trail of the Decepticon agent [[Flamewar (Transformers)|Flamewar]] for a long time, Bumblebee interrupts a communication between Flamewar and the [[Tripredacus Council]] and reveals that his agent, [[Ricochet (Transformers)|Ricochet]], has installed a degenerative virus into [[Deathsaurus]]'s clone army. With Flamewar now exposed, Bumblebee points out that she was nothing more than a liability to the Council, who blow her ship up. Based on the Transformers Classics toy line, the Timelines 2007 story is set 15 years after the end of the [[Marvel Comics]] story (ignoring all events of the [[Marvel UK]] and ''Generation 2'' comics). Megatron has survived the crash of the ''[[Ark (Transformers)|Ark]]'' on Earth, reformatted himself into a new form, and now leads [[Ramjet (Transformers)|Ramjet]], [[Skywarp]], [[Soundwave (Transformers)|Soundwave]], [[Starscream (Transformers)|Starscream]], and the [[Constructicons]]. [[Optimus Prime]] has also returned to Earth commanding Bumblebee, [[Cliffjumper]], [[Grimlock]], [[Jetfire]], [[Mirage (Transformers)|Mirage]], and [[Rodimus]] (formerly [[Rodimus|Hot Rod]]). In ''Crossing Over'', when the Cybertronians [[Skyfall (Transformers)|Skyfall]] and [[Landquake]] arrive on Earth unexpectedly Megatron attempts to destroy them, but Optimus Prime and his Autobots are able to drive Megatron away. Bumblebee appears in the story ''[[Generation 2: Redux]]'' in which he is among the reinforcements from [[Autobot City]] to respond to the Decepticon attack at the [[Large Hadron Collider]] in [[Switzerland]]. Once there, the Autobots are able to defeat the Decepticons, but during the fight the Autobots are exposed to refined [[Forestonite]], which enhances and mutates Cybertronian systems. He gets enhanced to his ''Generation 2'' form.{{Cite comic |writer=[[Greg Sepelak]] & [[Trent Troop]] |penciller=[[Robby Musso]] |inker=[[Robby Musso]] & [[Frank Milkovich]] |story=Generation 2: Redux |title=Transformers Timelines |volume=2 |issue=5 |date=Summer 2010 |publisher=[[Fun Publications]] |location=Fort Worth, Texas}} ==== IDW Publishing ==== Fall of 2005 was the third re-launch for [[Transformers (comics)|the ''Transformers'' comic series]], this time under the management of [[IDW Publishing]]. IDW's core universe was introduced with the six-issue mini-series, ''[[The Transformers: Infiltration]]'', making it clear that the company's take on the Generation 1 universe was radically different. Bumblebee appears as a member of a small team of Autobots under the command of [[Prowl (Transformers)|Prowl]], operating in secret on Earth out of ''Ark-19''. Still a Volkswagen Beetle, he (like the other Autobots) possesses the added ability to generate a "holo-matter" avatar of a young female to masquerade as a driver and to otherwise interact with humans. Working with [[Ratchet (Transformers)|Ratchet]] and a trio of young humans to search an abandoned Decepticon base, Bumblebee is able to take down [[Skywarp]] during a Decepticon attack, out-thinking the Decepticon and shooting him out of the sky despite his teleportation system. After [[Blitzwing]] and Skywarp bring the base down, Bumblebee helps save the humans, despite commenting previously that they would be acceptable losses. As Megatron then engages the traitorous Starscream in battle, Bumblebee does what he does best by spying on the fight; almost shot by the [[Lists of Transformers characters|Battlechargers]], he is saved by Prowl and [[Jazz (Transformers)|Jazz]]. In the follow-up, ''[[The Transformers: Escalation]]'', he is left to run the ''Ark-19'' on his own. Bumblebee was among the Autobots who opposed the Decepticons serving the elder gods in the [[IDW Publishing]] ''Infestation 2: Transformers'' comic.{{cite comic |colorist=Joana Lafuente |date=February 2011 |editor=Bobby Curnow |inker=John Wycough |issue=1 |letterer=Chris Mowry |penciller=Guido Guidi |publisher=IDW Publishing |story=|title=Infestation 2: The Transformers |volume=1 |writer=Chuck Dixon}} ====TFcon comics==== Bumblebee, voiced by Dan Gilvezan, appeared in the TFcon 2009 voice actor play ''Bee for, Bee now''.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OBTlU6PT9LA |title=Part 1 - TFCon 2009 Voice Actor Script Reading |website=YouTube |accessdate=November 1, 2013}} Bumblebee appears among the characters in ''Re-Unification'', the 2010 TFCon voice actor play prelude comic.{{cite web |url=http://www.tfcon.ca/gallery/TFcon-2010-Prelude-Comic |title=Prelude Comic |website=TFcon.com |access-date=8 October 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100922121254/http://www.tfcon.ca/gallery/TFcon-2010-Prelude-Comic |archive-date=September 22, 2010}} ===Games=== Bumblebee was one of eight playable characters in the 1986 [[Commodore 64]] video game ''[[Transformers: The Battle to Save the Earth]]''. The ''Classic'' toy line appeared in a simple [[Adobe Flash|Flash]]-based video game on the Hasbro web site called ''[[Transformers Battle Circuit]]''. In this one-on-one fighting game, players press the right and left arrow keys to try to overpower their opponent. Playable characters include Rodimus, Bumblebee, Grimlock, Jetfire, Starscream, [[Astrotrain]], [[Trypticon]], and [[Menasor]]. Optimus Prime and Megatron each appear as the [[boss (video games)|boss]] the player must defeat to win the game.{{cite web |url=http://www.hasbro.com/monkeybartv/default.cfm?page=Entertainment/OnlineGames/GameSelect&game=1787 |title=Transformers Battle Circuit |website=Hasbro.com |accessdate=April 17, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100313083042/http://www.hasbro.com/monkeybartv/default.cfm?page=Entertainment%2FOnlineGames%2FGameSelect&game=1787 |archivedate=March 13, 2010 |df= }} Bumblebee appears in the 2003 video game ''[[Transformers (2003 video game)|Transformers]]'', voiced by Jack Merluzzi.{{cite web |url=http://www.maru-z.com/Maru_Z/Narration.html |title=Narration |website=maru-z.com |accessdate=August 13, 2017}} Bumblebee is one of the light-blue robots in the 2010 card game ''Monopoly Deal Transformers''. ===Other merchandise=== Popular Bumblebee-specific merchandise includes shirts and costumes based on the character.{{cite web |url=http://www.tvstoreonline.com/tvshows--transformers.html |title=Bumblebee Shirts & Costumes |website=TV Store Online |date=April 10, 2010 |accessdate=December 5, 2014}} {{-}} ===Other media=== A parody of the ''Generation 1'' Transformers was aired in the December 23, 2008, episode of ''[[Frank TV]]'', called "Frank the Halls". In the story, Optimus Prime and his Autobots (Bumblebee, Jazz, and Wheeljack) battle Megatron and his Decepticons (Soundwave and Starscream) when Optimus runs out of gas. Optimus becomes enraged at the price of gas, steals the fuel from the annoying hybrid Autobot [[Toyota Prius|Prius]] Maximus, then joins the Decepticons in destroying the city.{{cite web |url=http://doinkamation.blogspot.com/2008/12/transformers-satire-for-franktv.html |title=Animation Corner: Transformers Satire For FrankTV |website=Doinkamation.blogspot.com |date=December 3, 2008 |accessdate=April 27, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708033321/http://doinkamation.blogspot.com/2008/12/transformers-satire-for-franktv.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 8, 2011}} Bumblebee appears in the ''[[Robot Chicken]]'' episode "Junk in the Trunk". In the segment he is in, he is whipped by a towel used by Grimlock in the locker room and later appears at Optimus's bedside before he dies of prostate cancer. [[Maggie Simpson]] appeared as Bumblebee in [[Future-Drama|one episode]]'s [[The Simpsons opening sequence|opening sequence]] to ''[[The Simpsons]]'' alongside the rest of the Simpson family rendered as Autobots. ==''Transformers: Generation 2''== {{Transformers character | name = Bumblebee | image = | caption = | affiliation = Autobot | subgroup = Go-Bots | rank = 7 | height = | function = Clone | partner = [[Ironhide]], Mirage | motto = | alternatemodes = Car | series = ''[[Transformers: Generation 1]]''
''[[Transformers: Generation 2]]'' | engvoice = | japanvoice = }} '''Bumblebee''' is a clone of the original Bumblebee. ===Fun Publications=== In "Flash Forward, Part 3", [[Jhiaxus]], seeking to create a new unified faction of Transformers, "borrowed" personality components, forestonite, Hi-Q, and blueprints from Quantum Laboratories. One of these Transformers was a clone of Bumblebee. Bumblebee, along with the other clones, were introduced to Pyro as a second generation of Transformers. In "Flash Forward, Part 5", Bumblebee and Mirage greeted a clone of [[Sideswipe (Transformers)|Sideswipe]], unaware the clone was actually the original Sideswipe. In ''A Flash Forward, Part 6'', Bumblebee, Mirage, and Ironhide confronted the escaping Autobots, but Pyro convinced them to return to Earth with him. ===Toys=== *'''''Generation 2'' Go-Bot Bumblebee''' (1995) A redeco of Go-Bot High Beam, transforming into a yellow sports car. He features through-axle construction for incredibly fast zipping on flat, smooth surfaces, and is compatible with many tracks and playsets from Hot Wheels and Matchbox. This figure was later repurposed as the second-generation Bumblebee. This mold was also used to make ''Robots in Disguise'' (2001) Crosswise and Nightracer. ==Transformers: Armada== Bumblebee is the Japanese name of [[Perceptor]] in ''[[Transformers: Armada]]''. The Mini-Con Sparkplug was also based on the original Bumblebee, while [[Hot Shot (Transformers)|Hot Shot]] was in fact going to be named Bumblebee but had his name changed due to trademark reasons. ===Toys=== *'''''Super Collection Figure'' Bumble''' (2003) A PVC figurine was made for Perceptor/Bumble, part of the tenth act of Super Collection Figures made by Takara. There are two versions: one in cartoon colors and one in a silver color scheme. ==Transformers: Energon== {{Transformers character | name = Bumblebee | image = | caption = | affiliation = Autobot | subgroup = [[Rodimus]]'s crew | rank = | partner = | alternatemodes = Car | series = [[Transformers: Energon]] }} Bumblebee is a member of Rodimus's crew from ''[[Transformers: Energon]]''. He appears only in a flashback and looks exactly like his Generation 1 counterpart. ===Animated Series=== Led by Rodimus, the crew left Cybertron 8,000 years ago and created a new home world on the planet Omnitron. ==Transformers film universe== {{Transformers character | name = Bumblebee/ZB-7/B-127 | image = BumblebeeHIRES.jpg | caption = Bumblebee in the [[Transformers (film)|2007 Transformers movie]] | affiliation = Autobot | subgroup = Scout, Cyber Slammers, Deluxe Vehicles, Fast Action Battlers, Micro Vehicles, Supreme Vehicles, Human Alliance | rank = 5 | height = {{convert|16|-|18|ft|m|2|abbr=on}} | function = Guardian, Scout, Second In Command (AOE), Autobot leader (TLK) | partner = [[Optimus Prime#The Transformers|Optimus Prime]], [[Rodimus|Hot Rod]], [[Cliffjumper]], [[Arcee]], [[Jazz (Transformers)|Jazz]], [[Ratchet (Transformers)#Transformers|Ratchet]], NEST, [[Sam Witwicky]], [[Mikaela Banes]], [[Carly Spencer]], [[Skids (Transformers)|Jolt]], [[Wheeljack]], [[Mirage (Transformers)|Mirage]], [[Ironhide]], [[Hound (Transformers)|Hound]], Crosshairs, Strafe, [[Drift (Transformers)|Drift]], Wheelie, Brains, Cade Yeager, Tessa Yeager, Shane Dyson, Izabella, Sir Edmund Burton, Viviane Wembley, Charlie Watson | motto = "''Don't worry about the size of the blaster-worry about the sting!''",{{cite web "I Sting like a bee!" | alternatemodes = Entry mode protoform, Mercedes-Benz 770, Volkswagen Beetle, [[Chevrolet Camaro (second generation)#1977|1977 Chevrolet Camaro]], [[Chevrolet Camaro (fifth generation)|2006 Chevrolet Camaro concept/2009 Chevrolet Camaro]] / 1976 Chevrolet Camaro SS/2014 Chevrolet Camaro concept/custom-built 2016 Camaro ZL1 | series = ''[[Transformers (film series)|Transformers Cinematic Universe]]''
