revision.text:
{{For|the 2018 remake|Shadow of the Colossus (2018 video game)}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox video game | image = Sotc boxart.jpg | caption = The game cover emphasizes the massive size of the colossus compared to the protagonist | developer = {{ubl|[[SCE Japan Studio]]|[[Team Ico]]}} | publisher = [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] | platforms = [[PlayStation 2]]<!--The PS3 remaster and PS4 remake have their own articles, do not add PS3/PS4 here--> | released = {{Video game release|NA|October 18, 2005|JP|October 27, 2005|AUS|February 16, 2006|EU|February 17, 2006}} | genre = [[Action-adventure game|Action-adventure]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]] | director = [[Fumito Ueda]] | producer = [[Kenji Kaido]] | designer = Fumito Ueda | writer = {{ubl|Fumito Ueda|Junichi Hosono|Masashi Kudo|Takashi Izutani}} | composer = [[Kow Otani]] }} '''''Shadow of the Colossus''''', released in Japan as ''Wander and the Colossus'',{{efn|{{nihongo|ワンダと巨像|Wanda to Kyozō}} in Japanese}} is an [[action-adventure game]] developed by [[SCE Japan Studio]] and [[Team Ico]], and published by [[Sony Computer Entertainment]] for the [[PlayStation 2]]. The game was released in North America and Japan in October 2005 and [[PAL region]]s in February 2006.<ref name="release info">{{cite web | editor=IGN site staff | year=2006 | title=IGN: Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://ps2.ign.com/objects/490/490849.html | work=IGN | accessdate=July 29, 2006}}</ref> It was directed by [[Fumito Ueda]] and developed at SCEI's International Production Studio 1, also known as [[Team Ico]]; the same development team responsible for the cult hit ''[[Ico]]'',<ref name="cult-eurogamer">{{cite web | author=Reed, Kristan | title=The Bluffer's Guide To PS2 Cult Classics | url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=56384 | work=Eurogamer.net|accessdate=April 12, 2007}}</ref><ref name="psau">{{cite web | author=PlayStation.com Australia site staff | title=NICO: the game that never was | url=http://au.playstation.com/news/sotc_nico.jhtml | work=PlayStation.com Australia |accessdate=July 30, 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060829145228/http://au.playstation.com/news/sotc_nico.jhtml |archivedate = August 29, 2006|deadurl=yes}}</ref> to which the game is considered a [[spiritual successor]].
The game's storyline focuses on a young man named Wander who enters a forbidden land. Wander must travel across a vast expanse on horseback and defeat sixteen massive beings, known simply as colossi,<ref name="inishie1">{{Cite book | year=2006 | editor= of Famitsū | title=Wander to Kyozō Kōshiki Kōryaku & Setteibon Inishie no Chi Kitan | page=140 | language=Japanese | publisher=Enterbrain}}</ref> in order to restore the life of a girl named Mono. The game is unusual within the action-adventure genre in that there are no towns or [[dungeon (games)|dungeons]] to explore, no characters with whom to interact, and no enemies to defeat other than the colossi.<ref name="colossalcreation">{{cite web |author1=McNamara, Andy |author2=Berghammer, Billy |lastauthoramp=yes | year=2006 | title=Colossal Creation: The Kenji Kaido and Fumito Ueda Interview | url=http://www.gameinformer.com/News/Story/200602/N06.0216.1853.30213.htm | work=Game Informer | accessdate=July 9, 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060903065641/http://www.gameinformer.com/News/Story/200602/N06.0216.1853.30213.htm |archivedate = September 3, 2006|deadurl=yes}}</ref><ref name="behindtheshadow">{{cite news | author=Kohler, Chris | title=Behind the Shadow: Fumito Ueda | url=https://www.wired.com/news/technology/0,70286-0.html | work=Wired News | accessdate=July 9, 2006 | date=March 9, 2006 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060629071507/http://www.wired.com/news/technology/0,70286-0.html | archivedate=June 29, 2006 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> ''Shadow of the Colossus'' has been described as a [[Puzzle video game|puzzle game]], as each colossus can only be killed by attacking certain weak points which require specific actions to access.<ref name="gamespotreview">{{cite web | author=Shoemaker, Brad | date=October 17, 2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus for PlayStation 2 Review | url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/shadow-of-the-colossus-review/1900-6135831/ | work=GameSpot | accessdate=April 29, 2014}}</ref><ref name="eurogamer">{{cite web | author=Reed, Kristan | year=2005 | title=Review – Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=61436 | work=Euro Gamer | accessdate=July 21, 2006}}</ref>
Cited as an influential title in the video game industry and one of the [[List of video games considered the best|greatest games of all time]], ''Shadow of the Colossus'' is often regarded as an important example of [[video games as an art form|video game as art]] due to its [[minimalist]] landscape designs, immersive gameplay and emotional journey. It received wide critical acclaim by the media and was met with strong sales compared to ''Ico'', due in part to a larger marketing campaign. The soundtrack was also widely praised. The game won several awards for its audio, design, and overall quality. ''Shadow of the Colossus'' is also referenced numerous times in debates regarding the art quality and emotional perspectives of video games.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/2010/07/okay_kids_play_on_my_lawn.html |work=Chicago Sun-Times |title=Okay, kids, play on my lawn |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100811003526/http://blogs.suntimes.com/ebert/2010/07/okay_kids_play_on_my_lawn.html |archivedate=August 11, 2010 |df=mdy }}</ref>
A remastered version for the [[PlayStation 3]] was developed by [[Bluepoint Games]] and released alongside ''Ico'' as ''[[The Ico & Shadow of the Colossus Collection]]'' in September 2011. It features [[High-definition video|high-definition]] (HD) graphics, content previously missing from the North American version, [[PlayStation Network Trophies]], and 3D support.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.us.playstation.com/2010/09/15/ico-and-shadow-of-the-colossus-collection-hits-ps3-spring-2011-with-3d/|title=Ico and Shadow of the Colossus Collection hits PS3 Spring 2011 with 3D|date=September 15, 2010|last=Shuman|first=Sid|publisher=[[Sony Computer Entertainment America|SCEA]]|accessdate=September 16, 2010}}</ref> The HD version was released separately in Japan. A [[Shadow of the Colossus (2018 video game)|high-definition remake]] for the [[PlayStation 4]] was released in February 2018.
==Gameplay== Progression through ''Shadow of the Colossus'' occurs in cycles. Beginning at a central point in an expansive landscape, the player seeks out and defeats a colossus, and is then returned to the central point to repeat the process.<ref name="gamespotreview" /> To find each colossus, Wander may raise his sword while in a sunlit area to reflect beams of light, which will converge when the sword is pointed in the right direction of the next encounter.<ref name="ignpreview2">{{cite web | author=Dunham, Jeremy | year=2005 | title=Pre-E3 2005: Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/608/608001p1.html | work=IGN | accessdate=August 16, 2006}}</ref> The journey to a colossus is seldom a straightforward matter: stretches of varied terrain often require that a detour be taken along the way. Most colossi are located in remote areas, such as atop cliffs or within ancient structures.<ref name="gamespotreview"/><ref name="IGN-Guide">{{cite web| url = http://guides.ign.com/guides/490849/index.html| title = Guides: Shadow of the Colossus Walkthrough| publisher = IGN| accessdate = April 29, 2014| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120813232259/http://guides.ign.com/guides/490849/index.html| archivedate = August 13, 2012}}</ref>
[[File:SotCglyphstab.JPG|left|thumb|Wander climbs the first colossus to stab the sigil on its forehead. The [[HUD (video gaming)|heads-up display]] shows the character's health and stamina (lower right), as well as the colossus' health (upper left).]]
Once a colossus is found, the player must discover its weaknesses to defeat it. Each colossus dwells in a unique lair, and many colossi cannot be defeated without making use of the surrounding environment.<ref name="ignpreview3">{{cite web | author=Sulic, Ivan | year=2005 | title=A Colossus Falls | url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/641/641470p1.html | work=IGN | accessdate=August 16, 2006}}</ref> Every colossus has at least one weak point, indicated by a glowing [[sigil (magic)|sigil]]<ref name="giantleap">{{cite news | author=Kohler, Chris | title=Colossus Is Giant Leap for Games | url=https://www.wired.com/news/games/0,2101,69334,00.html | work=Wired News | accessdate=July 17, 2006 | date=October 26, 2005 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060618123156/http://www.wired.com/news/games/0,2101,69334,00.html | archivedate=June 18, 2006 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> that can be illuminated and identified by the sword's reflected light.<ref name="ignpreview2" /><ref name="ignpreview4">{{cite web | author=Dunham, Jeremy | year=2005 | title=E3 2005: Shadow of the Colossus Update | url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/616/616095p1.html | work=IGN |accessdate=August 16, 2006}}</ref> Each colossus has areas covered with fur or protruding ledges, which Wander may use to grip and scale the colossus while it thrashes about in an attempt to dislodge him.<ref name="gamespotreview" /> While scaling a colossus, the player must act quickly, as Wander has a limited stamina gauge that decreases while he hangs onto the creature.
Wander and the colossi have [[Health (game mechanism)|life bars]] to indicate their remaining health. A colossus' health will decrease significantly when its weak points are attacked, while Wander can be harmed by a colossus' attacks or a fall from great height. Throughout the game, Wander is equipped with only a sword and a bow with arrows,<ref name="giantleap" /> but may obtain other weapons from completing the Time Attack trials.
While the colossi are the only enemies, there are natural animals in the environment. Only one species, however, has any effect on gameplay: eating the tail of a certain kind of lizard increases Wander's stamina gauge. Likewise, the player may find fruit that increases Wander's maximum health.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://guides.ign.com/guides/490849/page_5.html | title=''Shadow of the Colossus'' Guide | publisher=IGN | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120813074738/http://guides.ign.com/guides/490849/page_5.html | archivedate = August 13, 2012}}</ref>
Wander's horse, Agro,<ref>''Shadow of the Colossus'' instruction book. [[Sony Computer Entertainment]], 2005. pp. 14–16.</ref> plays a large role in the game. In addition to serving as a means of transportation, fighting from horseback is vital to defeating some of the colossi.<ref name="ignpreview">{{cite web | author=Gantayat, Anoop | year=2005 | title=Wanda and Colossus | url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/546/546753p1.html | work=IGN | accessdate=August 16, 2006}}</ref> There are, however, many environments that cannot be traversed by horse, and colossi often inhabit areas within deep water or beyond large obstacles that must be scaled. Agro cannot travel beyond these, and when separated from Wander by such obstacles, cannot participate in the following battle.<ref name="ignpreview2" /> Agro is referred to as a male in the English-language version of the game,<ref>Sony Computer Entertainment. Shadow of the Colossus. (Sony Computer Entertainment). PlayStation 2. (October 18, 2005) "Kick the side of the horse to make him run by using X."</ref> though director Fumito Ueda said that he saw Wander's horse as female.<ref name="inishie2">{{Cite book | year=2006 | editor= of Famitsū | title=Wander to Kyozō Kōshiki Kōryaku & Setteibon Inishie no Chi Kitan | page=202 | language=Japanese | publisher=Enterbrain}}</ref>
The environment must be used to the player's advantage more often as the game progresses. The first two battles take place on simple, large, flat areas of land, with the only goal being to discover how to scale the colossi and attack their weak points.<ref name="ignpreview2" /><ref name="ignpreview3" /> However, the majority of the following fourteen battles require that some aspect of the battlefield be used.<ref name="eurogamer" /><ref name="ignreview">{{cite web | last=Roper | first=Chris | year=2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Review | url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/658/658991p1.html | work=IGN | accessdate=July 21, 2006}} Page 2.</ref>
== Plot and setting == During ''Shadow of the Colossus'', the player receives little information concerning the backstories of the characters and their relationships with one another.<ref name="gamespotreview" /> The game takes place in a [[fantasy]] setting,<ref name="gamespyreview">{{cite web | author=McGarvey, Sterling | year=2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Review | url=http://ps2.gamespy.com/playstation-2/ico-ii/658966p1.html | work= GameSpy | accessdate=August 17, 2006}}</ref><ref name="fantasysetting">{{cite web | author=Daultrey, Stephen | year=2004 | title=An epic called Wanda: Sony's "awesome" PS2 works uncovered | url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=109139 | work=Computer and Videogames] | accessdate=August 17, 2006 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090918121008/http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=109139 | archive-date=September 18, 2009 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref> with most of the game's events occurring within a vast and unpopulated [[peninsula]], known as the Forbidden Land, separated from the outside world by a mountain range to its north and sea to the south and east. The presence of ruins and other ancient structures indicate the area was once a settlement.<ref name="ignreview2">{{cite web | last=Roper | first=Chris | year=2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Review | url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/658/658991p1.html | work=IGN|accessdate=July 21, 2006}} Page 3.</ref><ref name="ruins">{{cite web | author=Scott, Alan Marriott | year=2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Preview | url=http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/features/52381/Shadow_of_the_Colossus_Preview.html | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060104183914/http://www.g4tv.com/xplay/features/52381/Shadow_of_the_Colossus_Preview.html | archivedate=January 4, 2006 | work=G4 | accessdate=August 16, 2006}}</ref><ref name="newyorkmagazine">{{cite web | author=Hayes, Jonahthan | year=2005 | title=Larger than Life – New York Magazine Video Game Review | url=http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/arts/games/reviews/15173/ | work=New York Arts & Events | accessdate=July 28, 2006 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130104073143/http://newyorkmetro.com/nymetro/arts/games/reviews/15173/ | archivedate=January 4, 2013 | df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name="ruins2">{{cite web | author=Andrews, Stuart | date=February 22, 2006 | title=Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://www.trustedreviews.com/article.aspx?page=5814&head=0 | work=TrustedReviews | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070324085310/http://www.trustedreviews.com/gaming/review/2006/02/22/Shadow-of-the-Colossus/p2 | archivedate=March 24, 2007}}</ref>
The region is only accessible via a small cleft in the mountains to the north, leading to a massive stone bridge. This bridge spans half the distance of the landscape and terminates at a large temple called the "Shrine of Worship" located at its center. It is, however, forbidden to enter the land,<ref name="dorminandshrine">{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=PlayStation 2 |quote = '''Emon (narrating):''' That place... began from the resonance of intersecting points... They are memories replaced by ens and naught and etched into stone. Blood, young sprouts, sky—and the one with the ability to control beings created from light... In that world, it is said that if one should wish it one can bring back the souls of the dead... ...But to trespass upon that land is strictly forbidden...}}</ref> which is characterized by diverse geographical features, such as lakes, plateaus, canyons, caves, and deserts in addition to human-made structures.<ref name="gamespotreview" /><ref name="ignreview" />
=== Characters === [[File:Mono and Wander.JPG|thumb|Wander standing before Mono. Both Wander and Mono were designed with long hair from the start of the design process.]] The [[protagonist]] of the game is {{Nihongo|Wander|ワンダ|Wanda|voiced by [[Kenji Nojima]]}}, a young man whose goal is to resurrect a girl named {{Nihongo|Mono|モノ||voiced by [[Hitomi Nabatame]]}}. Little is known about Mono other than that she was a maiden who was somehow sacrificed because she was believed to have a cursed destiny.<ref name="dorminrequest">{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=[[PlayStation 2]]|quote='''Wander:''' She was sacrificed, for she has a cursed fate. Please, I need you to bring back her soul... / '''Dormin:''' That maiden's soul? Souls that are once lost cannot be reclaimed...is that not the law of mortals? With that sword, however...it may not be impossible. / '''Wander:''' Really?! / '''Dormin:''' That is, of course, if thou manage to accomplish what We askest. / '''Wander:''' What do I have to do? / '''Dormin:''' Behold the idols that stand along the wall... Thou art to destroy all of them. But those idols cannot be destroyed by the mere hands of a mortal... / '''Wander:''' Then what am I to do? / '''Dormin:''' In this land there exist colossi that are the incarnations of those idols. If thou defeat those colossi—the idols shall fall.}}</ref> Wander and Mono were designed with long hair from the start of the design process, with Mono's long hair specifically as a contrast to Yorda of ''Ico'', who has short hair.<ref name="inishie3">{{Cite book | year=2006 | editor= of Famitsū | title=Wander to Kyozō Kōshiki Kōryaku & Setteibon Inishie no Chi Kitan | page=173 | language=Japanese | publisher=Enterbrain|isbn=4-7577-2580-9}}</ref> Assisting Wander in his quest to revive her is his loyal horse, {{Nihongo|Agro|アグロ|Aguro}}, who serves as his only ally in defeating the colossi.<ref name="official site">{{cite web | author=Sony Computer Entertainment staff | year=2006 | title=Shadow of the Colossus English (UK) | url=http://www.shadowofthecolossus.com/ | work=Shadow of the Colossus official site | accessdate=July 29, 2006 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081013171137/http://www.shadowofthecolossus.com/ | archivedate=October 13, 2008 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> Wander also receives aid from an entity called {{Nihongo|Dormin|ドルミン|Dorumin|voiced by [[Kazuhiro Nakata]] and [[Kyōko Hikami]]}}. The story revolves around these characters but features a small supporting cast including Lord {{Nihongo|Emon|エモン||voiced by [[Naoki Bandō]]}} and his men.
Speaking with two voices at once (one male and one female), Dormin is a mysterious, disembodied entity. In [[legend]]s of the game's world, it is said that Dormin has the power to revive the dead;<ref name="dorminandshrine" /><ref name="official site" /> it is for this reason that Wander enters the forbidden land, seeking its assistance in reviving Mono. Dormin offers to revive her in exchange for Wander destroying the sixteen colossi.<ref name="dorminrequest"/> "Dormin", which spells "Nimrod" backwards, has been speculated to be a reference to the body of the biblical King [[Nimrod]] which was cut up and scattered.<ref name="ciccoricco" />
Lord Emon is a [[shamanism|shaman]] who narrates a vision in the game's introduction, vaguely explaining the origin of the land Wander has come to, and emphasizing that entry to this place is forbidden.<ref name="dorminandshrine" /> He is portrayed as having extensive knowledge regarding the nature and containment of Dormin, and the ability to use powerful [[magic (paranormal)|magic]]. He has a small group of warriors at his command, and is pursuing Wander to prevent the use of "the forbidden spell", the ritual involving the destruction of the sixteen colossi and the restoration of Dormin's power.<ref name="Shadow of the Colossus">{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote= '''Emon:''' Have you any idea what you've done?! Not only did you steal the sword and trespass upon this cursed land, you used the forbidden spell as well...}}</ref>
The colossi are armored, most often enormous creatures with forms ranging from various humanoids to predatory animals, and live in all manner of surroundings and environments, including beneath water and flying through the air. Their bodies are a fusion of [[organic matter|organic]] and [[Inorganic compound|inorganic]] parts such as rock, earth, fur, and [[architectural]] elements, some of which are weathered or fractured. Some colossi are peaceful and will only attack when provoked, while others are aggressive and will attack on sight.<ref name="gamespotreview" /><ref name="pressstart">{{cite web | author=Schilling, Chris | year=2006 | title=Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://www.pressstartonline.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=125&Itemid=43 | work=Press Start Online | accessdate=August 8, 2006 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060717235817/http://www.pressstartonline.co.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=125&Itemid=43 <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = July 17, 2006}}</ref> Inhabiting specific locations in the forbidden land, they do not venture outside their own territory. Once slain they will remain where fallen, as a mound of earth and rock vaguely resembling the original colossus.<ref name="crumble">{{cite news | author=Gillett, Nick | title=Preview Guitar Hero / Shadow Of The Colossus | url=https://www.theguardian.com/theguide/games/story/0,,1705970,00.html | work=[[Guardian Unlimited]] | accessdate=August 8, 2006 | location=London | date=February 11, 2006}}</ref><ref name="crumble2">{{cite web | author=IGN site staff | year=2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Cheats, Code and Cheat Codes | url=http://cheats.ign.com/ob2/068/490/490849.html | work=IGN | accessdate=August 8, 2006}}</ref> A pillar of light marks the location of each colossus after they are defeated. The [[Latin]] names of the colossi, though featured throughout fan related media, are not official and are never referred to within the game.
=== Story === The story of ''Shadow of the Colossus'' begins as Wander enters the forbidden land, traveling across the long bridge on his horse, Agro. Unknown to the player, prior to entering the forbidden land Wander had stolen an ancient sword, which is the only weapon capable of slaying the colossi of the forbidden land.<ref name="Shadow of the Colossus"/> Led to the massive Shrine of Worship at the center of the region, Wander carries with him the body of a maiden named Mono. A moment later, several man-like shadowy creatures appear and prepare to attack Wander before he easily dismisses them with a wave of the ancient sword in his possession. After vanquishing the shadow creatures, the voice of the disembodied entity known as "Dormin" echoes from above, expressing surprise that Wander possesses the weapon. Wander requests that Dormin return Mono's soul to her body, which Dormin states may be possible on the condition that Wander can destroy the sixteen [[cult image|idols]] lining the temple's hall by using the ancient sword to kill the sixteen colossi located throughout the land. Despite being warned by Dormin that he may have to pay a great price to revive Mono, Wander sets out to search the land for the colossi and destroy them.<ref>{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Dormin:''' But heed this, the price you pay may be heavy indeed. / '''Wander:''' It doesn't matter. }}</ref>
What Wander does not know is that the colossi contain portions of Dormin's own essence that were scattered long ago to render the entity powerless.<ref name="dorminrequest" /><ref name="dorminsealed">{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Dormin:''' Thou severed Our body into sixteen segments for an eternity in order to seal away Our power... }}</ref> As Wander kills each colossus, a released fragment of Dormin enters his body. Over time, the signs of Wander's deterioration from the gathered essence become clearer—his skin becoming paler, his hair darker, and dark streaks growing across his face. After the death of the twelfth colossus, it is revealed to the player that Wander is being pursued by a group of warriors led by Emon. Urged to hurry with his task by Dormin, Wander soon heads off to defeat the sixteenth and final colossus. On the way to this confrontation, he travels on horseback across a long bridge which begins to collapse as he is halfway across. At the last second when it seems he will not make it, Wander is thrown to the other side by Agro before the horse falls into the distant river below.
Soon after, Wander goes on to defeat the final colossus as Emon's company arrives in the Shrine of Worship to witness the last temple idol crumble. Wander appears back in the temple soon after, the signs of his corruption readily apparent: his skin is clammy, his eyes are milky, and a pair of tiny [[Horn (anatomy)|horns]] has sprouted from his head. Emon orders his warriors to kill the "[[Spirit possession|possessed]]" man as he approaches Mono and finally falls once stabbed through the heart by one of Emon's men.<ref>{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Emon:''' Eradicate the source of the evil. Look... He's possessed by the dead. Hurry up and do it! It is better to put him out of his misery than to exist, cursed as he is.}}</ref> However, a newly whole Dormin takes control of Wander's body and transforms into a shadowy giant.<ref name="dorminsealed"/><ref>{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Dormin:''' We have borrowed the body of this warrior... }}</ref> While his men flee, Lord Emon casts the ancient sword into a small pool at the back of the temple's hall to evoke a whirlwind of light that consumes Dormin and Wander, sealing Dormin within the temple once again. After fleeing with the bridge connecting to the temple collapsing behind them, forever isolating the forbidden land from the rest of the world, Emon expresses hope that Wander may be able to atone for his crimes should he have survived.<ref>{{cite video game|title=Shadow of the Colossus |developer=Sony Computer Entertainment |publisher=Sony Computer Entertainment |date=October 18, 2005 |platform=PlayStation 2|quote='''Emon:''' Poor ungodly soul... Now, no man shall ever trespass upon this place again. Should you be alive... If it's even possible to continue to exist in these sealed lands...one day, perhaps you will make atonement for what you've done. }}</ref> Back in the temple, Mono awakens and finds Agro limping into the temple with an injured hind leg. Mono follows Agro to the pool into which Wander and Dormin were pulled by Emon's spell, finding a male [[infant]] with tiny horns on his head. She takes the child with her, following the horse to higher levels of the Shrine of Worship, and arrives at a secret garden within the shrine as the game ends.
=== Connections to ''Ico'' === ''Shadow of the Colossus'' is considered both a [[spiritual successor]]<ref name="pressrelease">{{cite web|date=January 5, 2006 |title=The Long-Awaited Spiritual Successor to ICO Arrives Mid-February in Europe |editor=GameSpot site staff |url=http://www.gamespot.com/ps2/adventure/wandaandthecolossus/news.html?sid=6141938 |work=GameSpot |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121205234918/http://www.gamespot.com/news/the-long-awaited-spiritual-successor-to-ico-arrives-mid-february-in-europe-6141938 |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> and prequel to ''[[Ico]]''.<ref name="colossalcreation" /> For several months during and after the game's release, the game's director and lead designer, [[Fumito Ueda]], maintained that the game's status as a prequel was simply his personal take on the game and not necessarily its [[canon (fiction)|canon]] nature, as he largely intended for players to decide the specifics of the story for themselves, but he confirmed the two do have a connection.<ref name="behindtheshadow" /> Moreover, the shadowy figures which appear in the Shrine of Worship are connected to the shadows which the player must fight in ''Ico''.<ref name="official site" /> Both games feature "horned" characters for protagonists (Wander sprouts horns at the end of the game). The Queen's Sword from ''Ico'' is also available as a bonus unlockable item.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://faqs.ign.com/articles/882/882202p1.html | publisher=IGN | title=Shadow of the Colossus walkthrough | last=Reynolds | first=Matthew | accessdate=June 6, 2009 | date=May 7, 2006}}</ref> Both games also use unique [[fictional language]]s.<ref name="languages">{{cite web | author=The Gaming Intelligence Agency site staff | year=2001 | title=Interview with Fumito Ueda | url=http://terror.snm.zhdk.ch/mirrors/thegia/sites/www.thegia.com/features/f010831.html | work=The Gaming Intelligence Agency | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309132917/http://thegia.psy-q.ch/sites/www.thegia.com/features/f010831.html | archivedate=March 9, 2012}}</ref>
== Development == With a team of thirty-five people, ''Shadow of the Colossus'' began development in 2002 under the project name ''Nico'' (a [[portmanteau]] of ''ni'', [[2]] in Japanese, and "Ico")<ref name="dengeki">{{cite web | editor=Dengeki PlayStation staff | year=2005 | title=Interview Wander to Kyozō | url=http://dol.dengeki.com/soft/recommend/wander/ | work=Dengeki Online | accessdate=March 12, 2008 | language=Japanese }} Translation of paragraph 1<!--trans by [[:Special:Contributions/87.231.15.102|87.231.15.102]]-->:<br />'''Ueda Fumihito''': ''In the first stages of development, "Wander to Kyozō" was called "Nico," short for "Next Ico." The idea for our new game was to use what we had learned in "Ico" and come up with something new. However, "Nico" was nothing more than a temporary project name and it was clear from the beginning that the title would change''.</ref> and was intended to be a sequel to ''Ico''.<ref name="psau" /><ref name="makingcolossalgames">{{cite web | author=Kosak, Dave "Fargo" | year=2006 | title=Making Colossal Games | url=http://ps2.gamespy.com/playstation-2/ico-ii/688379p2.html | work=GameSpy | accessdate=July 18, 2006}}</ref> An early [[technology demo]] for the project shown at the [[DICE Summit]] in 2003 depicted a group of masked, horned boys riding horses while attacking and defeating a colossus.<ref name="psau" /><ref name="makingcolossalgames" /> However, Fumito Ueda expressed that, at the time, it was simpler to reuse the character design of ''Ico''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s protagonist, and that he never explicitly desired a sequel to ''Ico''.<ref name="psnz">{{cite web |editor1=PlayStation.com New Zeal |editor2=site staff | title=A Colossus Speaks | url=http://www.nz.playstation.com/news/shadow_of_the_colossus_qna.jhtml;jsessionid=PKA23GLV1NC5XS3YIXZCFE4LXBC5GIV0 | archive-url=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160523184714/http://www.nz.playstation.com/news/shadow_of_the_colossus_qna.jhtml;jsessionid=PKA23GLV1NC5XS3YIXZCFE4LXBC5GIV0 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=May 23, 2016 | work=PlayStation.com New Zealand |accessdate=July 30, 2006}}</ref> Japanese [[pre-order]]s of ''Shadow of the Colossus'' later included a bonus [[DVD]] with the concept video, a trailer describing ''Nico''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s plot, and an introduction the development team states they wanted to use in ''Shadow of the Colossus''.
Ueda and producer Kenji Kaido held their team to a high standard throughout production. An admitted perfectionist, Ueda felt that only one or two out of 500 artists who applied to work on ''Shadow of the Colossus'' met his criteria, and often demanded thorough changes in design until it matched his vision.<ref name="makingcolossalgames" /> For his part, Kaido challenged the programmers to meet the concept of realistic physics in relation to the movement of the colossi and the subsequent effect this movement would have for Wander, both in terms of how he might be displaced and how he may be able to use this movement to his advantage. For instance, if a colossus were to shake, Kaido wanted Wander's position to shift realistically in response. Additionally, if a colossus' limb was currently horizontal, Kaido wanted the player to be able to run across the limb as though it were any other flat surface. He referred to these two concepts as "player dynamics and reactions" and "organic collision deformation".<ref name="makingcolossalgames" /> The realistic physics engine produced as a result required that faster colossi had to be smaller as well.<ref name="psnz" />
[[File:Kaido Kenji And Fumito Ueda.jpg|thumb|left|[[Kenji Kaido]], producer of the game, and [[Fumito Ueda]], lead designer of the game at Art Futura 2005]] Ueda wished the game to have a unique presentation<ref name="colossalcreation" /> and change how both players and developers perceived the idea of what [[boss (video games)|bosses]] should be in video games. To achieve this, he ensured that the game's only enemies would be the sixteen colossi, that they could only be approached one at a time, and that they would have various behavior patterns.<ref name="psnz" /><ref name="1up">{{cite web|author=Mielke, James |year=2005 |title=Shadow Talk: Interview with Fumito Ueda and Kenji Kaido |url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3144673 |work=1UP.com |accessdate=July 23, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120629175723/http://www.1up.com/features/shadow-talk |archivedate=June 29, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Though limiting the presence of enemies to only bosses was partly intended to differentiate the game from others, Ueda also expressed that it was to ensure that the programmers' focus was entirely on the colossi so that their quality would be as high as possible.<ref name="behindtheshadow" /> In accordance with this focus upon the colossi—and his preference for simple controls—he intended that one button on the [[game controller]] be used solely for targeting the colossi during battles.<ref name="1up" /> Ueda cited ''[[The Legend of Zelda]]'' as an influence on the boss design, referring to the bosses as "inverted Zelda dungeons."<ref>{{cite web|title=Shadow of the Colossus|author=Tim Rogers|website=Insert Credit|url=http://archives.insertcredit.com/reviews/wanda/|date=October 25, 2005}}</ref>
A theme of companionship between the player and an [[game artificial intelligence|AI]]-controlled partner was a concern for Ueda.<ref name="1up" /> In ''Ico'', this theme was presented through the protagonist and the character Yorda, whom the player was required to work with and protect while navigating the game's environments.<ref name="1up2">{{cite web|author1=Mielke, James |author2=Rybicki, Joe |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2005 |title=A Giant In The Making |url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?pager.offset=2&cId=3143702 |work=1UP.com |accessdate=July 30, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130306095204/http://www.1up.com/do/feature?pager.offset=0&cId=3143702 |archivedate=March 6, 2013 |df= }}</ref> Similarly, a key element in ''Shadow of the Colossus'' is the relationship between Wander and his horse, Agro.<ref name="ignpreview" /> Intended to be a realistic representation of a horse, Agro will occasionally ignore commands. In Ueda's words, "a real horse ... doesn't always obey. It's not like a car or a motorcycle, it won't always turn when you say 'turn!'" However, he has admitted that the team had to seek a balance in how often Agro did not respond to commands so as to not sacrifice playability in the pursuit of realism.<ref name="1up" />
All elements of the game—including audio, gameplay and visuals—were used to achieve an atmosphere of a "[[loner|lonely hero]]", which Ueda considered important in the development of the game. Lighting, in particular, was used to establish a dark, fearsome setting for the forbidden land, while the protagonist's sword would provide a means of navigation that was "direct and only expressible visually".<ref name="1up2" /> Like ''Ico'', ''Shadow of the Colossus'' uses a distinct style of lighting. The game's [[game engine|engine]] uses elements such as [[saturation (color theory)|desaturated colors]], [[motion blur]] and partial [[high dynamic range rendering]], with a heavy emphasis on [[bloom (shader effect)|bloom lighting]].<ref name="eurogamer" /><ref name="ignpreview" /><ref name="makingofsotc">{{cite web|author=Nishikawa |year=2005 |title=Shadow of the Colossus PS2 Preview |url=http://www.watch.impress.co.jp/game/docs/20051207/3dwa.htm |work=Impress Watch |accessdate=August 2, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060820162258/http://www.watch.impress.co.jp/game/docs/20051207/3dwa.htm |archivedate=August 20, 2006 |df= }} Translation available at [https://web.archive.org/web/20060216113144/http://www.dyingduck.com/sotc/making_of_sotc.html The Making of "Shadow of the Colossus"]</ref>
A PlayStation 3 remastered version of ''Ico'' and ''Shadow of the Colossus'' was announced at Tokyo Game Show 2010 and released in September 2011. Developed by [[Bluepoint Games]], both were improved graphically to take advantage of the PlayStation 3's hardware and [[HDTV]]s, with numerous other improvements implemented.
=== PAL release === The [[PAL region|PAL]] version of the game was released in February 2006. Much like the PAL release for ''Ico'', the game came in cardboard packaging displaying various pieces of artwork from the game, and contained four art cards.<ref name="extrasandico">{{cite web | editor=Wales, Matt | year=2006 | title=PAL Colossus gets exclusive content | url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=133500 | work=computerandvideogames | accessdate=July 17, 2006}}</ref><ref name="artcards">{{cite web | editor=Li, Felix M.C. a.k.a. "Maskrider" | year=2006 | title=Zone of the Gamers: Wanda to Kyozou/Shadow of the Colossus Scans/Photos | url=http://z-o-g.org/gallery2/ico/watc/ | work=Zone Of the Gamers | accessdate=July 17, 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060717013014/http://z-o-g.org/ |archivedate = July 17, 2006|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
The game also came with a "making of" documentary, a trailer for ''Ico'' and a gallery of [[concept art]], accessible from the game's main menu.<ref name="extrasandico" /> Sony Computer Entertainment also re-released ''Ico'' in PAL territories at the time of ''Shadow of the Colossus''{{'}}s release, both to promote the game through ''Ico''{{'}}s reputation, and to allow players who did not buy ''Ico'' during its original limited release to "complete their collections".<ref name="extrasandico" /><ref name="icorerelease">{{cite web | editor=Wales, Matt | year=2006 | title=Fumito Ueda | url=http://www.computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=132780 | work=computerandvideogames | accessdate=July 17, 2006 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725002609/http://www.computerandvideogames.com/132780/interviews/fumito-ueda/ | archive-date=July 25, 2011 | dead-url=yes | df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Some confusion has arisen in PAL regions concerning the official name of the protagonist primarily because of the manual's usage of "Wanda", while the North American manual and the game itself uses the name "Wander". In fact, the Japanese version of the game spells the name "Wander" as ワンダ (''Wanda''), which is also the common transliteration of the English name "Wanda", hence the mistake in the manual.
=== Music === {{Infobox album | name = Shadow of the Colossus: Roar of the Earth (Original Game Soundtrack) | type = Soundtrack | artist = [[Kō Ōtani]] | cover = | alt = | released = December 7, 2005 | recorded = Victor Studio | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Video game music|Video game soundtrack]] | length = 75:36 | label = King Records | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }}
While the game has an extensive orchestral soundtrack, the music is only heard during [[cut scene]]s and colossus encounters, while time spent at the Shrine of Worship and traversing the landscape is silent save for the sounds made by the protagonist, his horse and their surroundings.<ref name="shadowreview">{{cite web | author=Ramsey | year=2006 | title=Review of Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://www.gamechew.com/review.php?id=2| work=GameChew | accessdate=July 29, 2006| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060621142435/http://www.gamechew.com/review.php?id=2| archivedate = June 21, 2006}}</ref> The open nature of the game world and lack of life, coupled with this limited use of music, aids in establishing an atmosphere of solitude,<ref name="1up2" /><ref name="instantreview">{{cite web|author=Rogers, Tim |year=2005 |title=Review of Shadow of the Colossus |url=http://www.insertcredit.com/reviews/wanda/ |work=insert credit |accessdate=July 29, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719000400/http://www.insertcredit.com/reviews/wanda/ |archivedate=July 19, 2006 |df= }}</ref> similar to that of ''Ico''.<ref name="ignreview" />
On December 7, 2005, a [[soundtrack album]] containing music from the game was released only in Japan, titled {{Nihongo|''Wander and the Colossus Original Soundtrack: Roar of the Earth''|ワンダと巨像 オリジナル サウンドトラック大地の咆哮|Wanda to Kyozō Original Soundtrack: Daichi no Hōkō|lead=1}}.<ref name="King Record Co., Ltd">{{cite AV media notes |url=http://vgmdb.net/album/96 |title=Wander and the Colossus Original Soundtrack: Roar of the Earth |page=8 |year=2005 |publisher=King Record Co., Ltd. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120722165035/http://vgmdb.net/album/96 |archivedate=July 22, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> There are currently no announced plans to release the album in other territories. The game's score was composed by [[Kow Otani]], whose previous video game work included the soundtracks to the PlayStation 2 flight simulator ''[[Sky Odyssey]]'' and the [[PlayStation]] shooter ''[[Philosoma]]''. He has also worked on several of the 1990s-era [[Gamera]] films, as well as a variety of [[anime]]. ''Roar of the Earth'' won the award for "Soundtrack of the Year" in the US-based [[video game magazine]] ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]''.<ref name="egmsoty">{{cite news |date=November 2005 | url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_zdegm/is_200511/ai_n15614448/pg_2 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080920021349/http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_zdegm/is_200511/ai_n15614448/pg_2 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2008-09-20 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Electronic Gaming Monthly | work=Find Articles | accessdate=July 30, 2006}}</ref>
=== Remake === {{main article|Shadow of the Colossus (2018 video game)}}
Sony announced a remake of ''Shadow of the Colossus'' for the [[PlayStation 4]] during their [[Electronic Entertainment Expo 2017]] press conference.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.destructoid.com/shadow-of-the-colossus-is-getting-a-remake-441922.phtml|title=Shadow of the Colossus is getting a remake|last=Valdez|first=Nick|date=June 12, 2017|work=[[Destructoid]]|accessdate=June 12, 2017}}</ref> It was released on February 6, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.gamespot.com/articles/ps4s-shadow-of-the-colossus-remaster-release-date-/1100-6454481/|title=PS4's Shadow Of The Colossus Remaster Release Date Confirmed|last=Dayus|first=Oscar|date=October 31, 2017|work=[[Gamespot]]|accessdate=October 31, 2017}}</ref> The remake is led by Bluepoint, who developed the earlier PlayStation 3 remaster. The developers remade all the game's assets from the ground up, but the game retains the same gameplay from the original title along with the introduction of a new control scheme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2017/06/14/shadow-of-the-colossus-on-ps4-is-true-remake/|title='Shadow of the Colossus' was rebuilt from the ground up for PS4|last=Fingas|first=Jon|date=June 14, 2017|work=[[Engadget]]|accessdate=June 14, 2017}}</ref> Ueda had since left Sony, but provided a list of recommended changes to Bluepoint for the remake; he stated that he does not believe many of them will be implemented, nor would they add any of the colossi that had been cut from the original game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-06-29-fumito-ueda-submitted-a-proposal-of-changes-for-the-shadow-of-the-colossus-ps4-remake|title=Fumito Ueda submitted a proposal of changes for the Shadow of the Colossus PS4 remake|last=Purchase|first=Robert|date=June 29, 2017|work=[[Eurogamer]]|accessdate=July 3, 2017}}</ref>
== Reception == ''Shadow of the Colossus''{{'}}s commercial reception was positive, with sales of 140,000 copies in its first week at retail in Japan, reaching number one in the charts. Almost 80% of the initial Japanese shipment was sold within two days.<ref name="sales">{{cite web | author=Fahey, Rob | year=2006 | title=Shadow of the Colossus goes in at number one | url=http://www.gamesindustry.biz/content_page.php?aid=12757 | work=Games Industry | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214102739/http://www.gamesindustry.biz/content_page.php?aid=12757 | archivedate=February 14, 2008}}</ref> These figures compare favorably with ''Ico'', which was well received by critics but failed to sell a significant number of units.<ref name="sales2">{{cite web | author=kellercl | year=2006 | title=PS2 Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://sony.controllerfreaks.com/review.asp?RevID=375 | work=ControllerFreaks | accessdate=July 24, 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070928121147/http://sony.controllerfreaks.com/review.asp?RevID=375 |archivedate = September 28, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The game was placed on Sony's list of [[List of Sony Greatest Hits games|Greatest Hits]] titles on August 6, 2006.<ref name="greatesthits">{{cite web | author=Surette, Tim | year=2006 | title=Five added to PS2 Greatest Hits | url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/five-added-to-ps2-greatest-hits/1100-6155274/ | work=GameSpot | accessdate=August 4, 2006}}</ref><ref name="greatesthits2">{{cite web | editor=Sony Computer Entertainment staff | year=2006 | title=PlayStation 2 – Greatest Hits | url=http://www.us.playstation.com/PS2/GreatestHits | work=PlayStation.com | accessdate=August 4, 2006|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060824233031/http://www.us.playstation.com/PS2/GreatestHits |archivedate = August 24, 2006|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
Unlike ''Ico'', ''Shadow of the Colossus'' received far more exposure, due in part to Sony putting its weight behind a massive advertising campaign.<ref name="kikizo">{{cite web | author=Kikizo site staff | year=2006 | title=Colossus Slays EA, Drags Ico Along | url=http://games.kikizo.com/news/200602/118.asp | work=Kikizo | accessdate=July 26, 2006}}</ref> It was advertised in game magazines, on [[television advertisement|television]] and on the [[Internet marketing|internet]], including a [[viral marketing]] campaign launched in October 2005. The site posted links to several websites claiming that the remains of five giants resembling certain colossi had been discovered in various parts of the world. The website has since been taken down. Some speculate that ''Ico''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s sales figures could have been improved if similar advertising efforts were made before its release.<ref name="eurogamer2">{{cite web | author=Reed, Kirstan | year=2005 | title=First Impressions – Shadow of the Colossus | url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=59445 | work=Euro Gamer | accessdate=July 26, 2006}}</ref>
=== Critical response === {{Video game reviews | GR = 91%<ref name="gamerankings">{{cite web |url=https://www.gamerankings.com/ps2/924364-shadow-of-the-colossus/index.html |title=Shadow of the Colossus for PlayStation 2 |work=[[GameRankings]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=September 12, 2018}}</ref> | MC = 91/100<ref name="metacritic">{{cite web |url=https://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-2/shadow-of-the-colossus |title=Shadow of the Colossus for PlayStation 2 Reviews |work=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=January 31, 2018}}</ref> | 1UP = A<ref name="1upreview">{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/shadow-colossus_5 |title=Shadow of the Colossus Review |last=Mielke |first=James |publisher=[[1UP.com]] |date=October 14, 2005 |accessdate=July 1, 2014 }}</ref> | Edge = 8/10<ref name="edge"/> | EGM = 8.8/10<ref name="egmsoty"/> | EuroG = 10/10<ref name="eurogamer"/> | Fam = 37/40<ref name=famitsu_overview /> | GI = 8.75/10 | GSpot = 8.7/10<ref name="gamespotreview"/> | GT = 9.3/10<ref name="gametrailers">{{cite web |url=http://www.gametrailers.com/reviews/oi7bf4/shadow-of-the-colossus-review |title=Shadow of the Colossus Review |publisher=[[GameTrailers]] |date=October 17, 2005 |accessdate=July 1, 2014 }}</ref> | IGN = 9.7/10<ref name="ignreview"/> | PSM = {{rating|4.5|5}} }}
''Shadow of the Colossus'' received critical acclaim, with an average critic score of 91% at [[GameRankings]],<ref name="gamerankings" /> making it the 11th-highest rated game of 2005.<ref>{{cite web | title=Gamerankings: 2005 games organized by score | url=http://www.gamerankings.com/browse.html?site=&cat=0&year=2005 | accessdate=March 31, 2012}}</ref> These include the Japanese magazine ''[[Famitsu]]'', who rated the game 37/40,<ref name=famitsu_overview>{{cite web|title=ワンダと巨像 (PS2)|url=http://www.famitsu.com/cominy/?m=pc&a=page_h_title&title_id=5|work=Famitsu.com|accessdate=April 29, 2014|language=Japanese}}</ref> the UK-based ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]'', who awarded an 8/10,<ref name="edge">{{Cite book | year=2005 | editor= of Edge magazine | title=Edge Christmas 2005; issue 157 | pages=98–99 | publisher=Future Publishing}}</ref> and ''Electronic Gaming Monthly'', who granted 8.8/10.<ref name="egmsoty" /> [[GameSpot]]'s review gave it an 8.7, commenting that "the game's aesthetic presentation is unparalleled, by any standard",<ref name="gamespotreview" /> while multimedia website [[IGN]] hailed the game as "an amazing experience" and "an absolute must-have title", rating it 9.7/10.<ref name="ignreview"/> [[GameSpy]] described it as "possibly the most innovative and visually arresting game of the year for the PS2".<ref name="gamespyreview" /> A retrospective ''Edge'' article described the game as "a fiction of unquestionable thematic richness, of riveting emotional power, whose fundamental artistic qualities are completely fused with its interactivity."<ref name="edge100">{{Cite book | year=2007 | title=Edge Presents The 100 Best Videogames | publisher=Future Publishing| page=146}}</ref> Dave Ciccoricco, a literature lecturer at the [[University of Otago]], praised the game for its use of long cutscenes and stretches of riding to make the player engage in self-reflection and feel immersed in the game world.<ref name="ciccoricco">{{cite book | last=Ciccoricco | first=Dave. | chapter='Play, Memory': ''Shadow of the Colossus'' and Cognitive Workouts | series=Dichtung Digital, Special Edition | title=New Perspectives on Digital Literature | editors=Ennslin, A. and Bell, A. | year=2008 | url=http://www.brown.edu/Research/dichtung-digital/2007/Ciccoricco/ciccoricco.htm | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928052422/http://www.brown.edu/Research/dichtung-digital/2007/Ciccoricco/ciccoricco.htm | archivedate=September 28, 2011}}</ref>
Many reviewers consider the game's soundtrack to be one of its greatest aspects. In addition to ''Electronic Gaming Monthly''{{'}}s award of "Soundtrack of the Year",<ref name="egmsoty" /> GameSpot commented that the musical score conveyed, and often intensified, the mood of any given situation,<ref name="gamespotreview" /> while it was described as "one of the finest game soundtracks ever" by a reviewer from [[Eurogamer]].<ref name="eurogamer" />
However, the game has been criticised for its erratic [[frame rate]], which is usually smooth while traversing the landscape, but often slows down in fast-paced situations, such as colossus battles.<ref name="gamespotreview" /> Concern was also expressed about the game's camera, which was described by GameSpy as being "as much of an opponent as the Colossi", "manag[ing] to re-center itself at the worst and most inopportune times".<ref name="gamespyreview" /> Reviewers are often mixed about Agro's AI and controls; while gaming website Thunderbolt insists the realism of Agro's movement and behaviour "create[s] a videogame experience unlike any other",<ref name="thunderbolt">{{cite web | author=Kramer, Josh | year=2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Review | url=http://www.thunderboltgames.com/reviews/viewreview.php?rid=767 | work=Thunderbolt | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080925180424/http://www.thunderboltgames.com/reviews/viewreview.php?rid=767 | archivedate=September 25, 2008}}</ref> ''Edge'' commented that the controls were "clumsy, crude, and unpredictable".<ref name="edge" /> Other critics like [[Game Revolution]]<ref name="gamerevreview">{{cite web | first=Ben | last=Silvermen | year=2005 | title=Shadow of the Colossus Review | url=http://www.gamerevolution.com/oldsite/games/ps2/adventure/shadow_of_the_colossus.htm | work=Game Revolution | accessdate=January 3, 2006 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060202023005/http://www.gamerevolution.com/oldsite/games/ps2/adventure/shadow_of_the_colossus.htm | archivedate=February 2, 2006 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> and GameSpot felt the game was too short (average playthrough time estimated 6 to 8 hours), with little replay value given the puzzle elements to each colossus battle.<ref name="gamespotreview" /><ref name="gamerevreview" />
=== Awards === ''Shadow of the Colossus'' has received several awards, including recognition for "Best Character Design", "Best Game Design", "Best Visual Arts" and "Game of the Year", as well as one of three "Innovation Awards" at the 2006 Game Developers Choice Awards.<ref name="eurogamer3">{{cite web | author=Fahey, Rob | year=2006 | title=Colossus looms over GDC Awards | url=http://www.eurogamer.net/article.php?article_id=63539 | work=Euro Gamer | accessdate=July 29, 2006}}</ref><ref name="gdc">{{cite web | author=Thorsen, Tor | year=2006 | title=Colossus casts shadow over GDC Awards | url=http://www.gamespot.com/articles/colossus-casts-shadow-over-gdc-awards/1100-6146480/| work=GameSpot | accessdate=July 30, 2006}}</ref> At the 2006 [[D.I.C.E. Summit|DICE Summit]], the game won the award for "Outstanding Achievement in Art Direction" at the [[Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences]],<ref name="aoiaas">{{cite web | author=GameSpy site staff | year=2006 | title=The 9th Annual Academy of Interactive Arts and Sciences Awards | url=http://www.gamespy.com/articles/687/687827p2.html | work=GameSpy | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105194414/http://www.gamespy.com/articles/687/687827p2.html | archivedate=November 5, 2012}}</ref> while it received one of two "Special Rookie Awards" at the Famitsu Awards 2005.<ref name="famitsuawards">{{cite web | author=Famitsu.com site staff | year=2006 | title="FAMITSU AWARDS 2005"大賞は『キングダム ハーツII』と『バイオハザード4』!! | url=http://www.famitsu.com/game/news/2006/04/21/103,1145605197,52094,0,0.html | work=Famitsu.com | accessdate=August 3, 2006}}</ref><ref name="famitsuawards2">{{cite web | author=Sony Computer Entertainment staff | year=2006 | title=Shadow of the Colossus 日本サイト | url=http://www.jp.playstation.com/scej/title/wander/prize.html | work=Shadow of the Colossus official site | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100127173939/http://www.jp.playstation.com/scej/title/wander/prize.html | archivedate=January 27, 2010}}</ref><ref name="famitsuawards3">{{cite web | author=Gantayat, Anoop | year=2006 | title=New Awards Discovered in Famitsu Awards Presentation | url=http://games.ign.com/articles/702/702910p1.html | work=IGN | accessdate=August 3, 2006}}</ref> It was nominated for "Best Original Music", "Best Artistic Graphics" and "Best PS2 Game", yet also "Most Aggravating Frame Rate" in GameSpot's awards for 2005,<ref name="awardnom">{{cite web|author=GameSpot site staff |year=2005 |title=GameSpot's Best of 2005 – Special Achievement Awards (pg 1) |url=http://gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=1 |work=GameSpot |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121209024516/http://www.gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=1 |archivedate=December 9, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name="awardnom2">{{cite web|author=GameSpot site staff |year=2005 |title=GameSpot's Best of 2005 – Special Achievement Awards (pg 8) |url=http://gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=8 |work=GameSpot |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121205234256/http://www.gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=8 |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name="awardnom3">{{cite web|author=GameSpot site staff |year=2005 |title=GameSpot's Best of 2005 – Special Achievement Awards (pg 5) |url=http://gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=5 |work=GameSpot |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121206034030/http://www.gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=5 |archivedate=December 6, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref><ref name="awardnom4">{{cite web|author=GameSpot site staff |year=2005 |title=GameSpot's Best of 2005 – Special Achievement Awards (pg 4) |url=http://gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=4 |work=GameSpot |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20121208150001/http://www.gamespot.com/pages/features/bestof2005/index.php?day=2&page=4 |archivedate=December 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> while it won "Best Adventure Game" and "Best Artistic Design" in IGN's Best of 2005 awards,<ref name="ignawards">{{cite web | editor=IGN site staff | year=2005 | title=IGN.com presents The Best of 2005 (pg 2) | url=http://bestof.ign.com/2005/overall/2.html | work=IGN | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206101635/http://bestof.ign.com/2005/overall/2.html | archivedate=December 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name="ignawards2">{{cite web | editor=IGN site staff | year=2005 | title=IGN.com presents The Best of 2005 (pg 14)| url=http://bestof.ign.com/2005/overall/14.html | work=IGN | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206112909/http://bestof.ign.com/2005/overall/14.html | archivedate=December 6, 2013}}</ref><ref name="ignawards3">{{cite web | editor=IGN site staff | year=2005 | title=IGN.com presents The Best of 2005 (pg 25)| url=http://bestof.ign.com/2005/overall/25.html | work=IGN | accessdate=April 29, 2014 | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206114833/http://bestof.ign.com/2005/overall/25.html | archivedate=December 6, 2013}}</ref> who cited Agro as the best sidekick in the history of video games.<ref name="agrotop10">{{cite web | author=IGN site staff | year=2006 | title=Top 10 Tuesday: Best Sidekicks | url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/698/698916p1.html | work=IGN | accessdate=July 29, 2006}}</ref> Two years after its release IGN listed ''Shadow'' as the fourth greatest PlayStation 2 game of all time.<ref name="ign25best">{{cite web|author=Dunham |year=2007 |title=The Top 25 PS2 Games of All Time |url=http://ps2.ign.com/articles/772/772296p1.html |work=IGN |accessdate=March 23, 2007 |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070605142021/http://ps2.ign.com/articles/772/772296p1.html |archivedate=June 5, 2007 |df= }}</ref> Games Radar awarded it Best Game of the Year 2006 (being released in the UK in early 2006, later than the US),<ref name="gamesradar">{{cite web|author=Games Radar Staff |year=2006 |title=Games Radar's 20 Best Games of 2006 |url=http://www.gamesradar.com/gb/xbox/game/features/article.jsp?articleId=20061222121859937003&releaseId=2006031312435546032&sectionId=1003&pageId=20061222122153390013 |work=Games Radar |accessdate=December 22, 2006 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> and appears in the site's "The 100 best games ever" list at number ten.<ref>http://www.gamesradar.com/best-games-ever/</ref> The game's ending was selected as the fourth greatest moment in gaming by the editors of ''[[GamePro]]'' in July 2006.<ref name="gamepro">{{cite web | author=GamePro editors | year=2006 | title=The 55 Greatest Moments in Gaming | url=http://www.gamepro.com/gamepro/domestic/games/features/75048.shtml | work=GamePro | accessdate=July 31, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060721175240/http://www.gamepro.com/gamepro/domestic/games/features/75048.shtml|archivedate=July 21, 2006}}</ref> The readers of [[PlayStation Official Magazine - UK|PlayStation Official Magazine]] voted it the 8th greatest PlayStation title ever released.<ref>PlayStation Official Magazine issue 50, [[Future Publishing]], October 2010</ref> [[Destructoid]] named the game #1 in their list of the top 50 video games of the decade.<ref>{{cite web|author=Concelmo, Chad |date=December 4, 2009 |title=The Top Video Games of the Decade (#10–1) |url=http://www.destructoid.com/the-top-50-videogames-of-the-decade-10-1--155591.phtml |work=[[Destructoid]] |accessdate=December 4, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141128064548/http://www.destructoid.com/the-top-50-videogames-of-the-decade-10-1--155591.phtml |archivedate=November 28, 2014 |df=mdy }}</ref> IGN named ''Shadow of the Colossus'' the best game of 2005,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/decade/best-games-2005.html|title=Best Videogames and Computer Games of 2005|work=[[IGN]]| accessdate=April 29, 2014| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130706041126/http://www.ign.com/decade/best-games-2005.html| archivedate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> and the second best game of the decade, behind ''[[Half-Life 2]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/decade/best-games-decade.html|title=Best Videogames and Computer Games of the Decade 2000–2009|work=[[IGN]]| accessdate=April 29, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130724080110/http://www.ign.com/decade/best-games-decade.html|archivedate=July 24, 2013}}</ref> In 2012, ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]'' magazine named ''Shadow of the Colossus'' the second-best PlayStation 2 game of all time, behind ''[[God of War II]]''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Knight|first=Rich|title=The 50 Best PS2 Games Ever: 2. Shadow of the Colossus|url=http://www.complex.com/video-games/2012/11/the-50-best-ps2-games-ever/shadow-of-the-colossus|publisher=Complex Media|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex.com]]|accessdate=December 28, 2012}}</ref> In 2015, the game placed 4th on USgamer's The 15 Best Games Since 2000 list.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Mike|title=The 15 Best Games Since 2000, Number 4: Shadow of the Colossus|url=http://www.usgamer.net/articles/the-15-best-games-since-2000-number-4-shadow-of-the-colossus|website=USgamer|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=August 6, 2015|date=August 5, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150806133958/http://www.usgamer.net/articles/the-15-best-games-since-2000-number-4-shadow-of-the-colossus|archivedate=August 6, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref>
== In other media == The game plays a significant role in the 2007 [[Mike Binder]] film ''[[Reign Over Me]]'' as one of the ways [[Adam Sandler]]'s character copes with his primary struggle – with aspects of the game mirroring the tragedy that befell Sandler's character; ''Shadow of the Colossus'' falling giants mirroring the crashing towers of the [[September 11 attacks]] in which his wife and children died, and the game's lead character trying to resurrect his deceased love are two of the main themes which strike a similarity. Sandler is said to have [[ad lib]]bed a detailed description of the control scheme in a scene with [[Don Cheadle]], who plays his old friend.<ref name="reignoverme">{{cite web| author=Ashcraft, Brian |date=March 22, 2007 |title=Feature: The Colossus and the Comedian |url=http://kotaku.com/gaming/top/feature-the-colossus-and-the-comedian-246286.php |work=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=January 18, 2010}}</ref> Both actors are said to have become experts at the game during the filming.<ref name="reignoverme" />
===Film adaptation=== In April 2009, it was reported that [[Sony Pictures]] would adapt ''Shadow of the Colossus'' into a film. [[Kevin Misher]], producer of ''[[The Scorpion King]]'', ''[[The Interpreter]]'' and the recent attempted remake of ''[[Dune (novel)#Future adaptation|Dune]]'', negotiated to produce. It was announced that Fumito Ueda, the game's creator, would be involved in the film's production.<ref name="fumitoinvolve">{{cite web| author=Totilo, Stephen |date=September 28, 2009 |title=Shadow Of The Colossus Creator Hints At Movie Involvement, Wants PS3 Ports |url=http://kotaku.com/5368694/shadow-of-the-colossus-creator-hints-at-movie-involvement-wants-ps3-ports |work=[[Kotaku]] |accessdate=September 29, 2009}}</ref> On May 23, 2012, it was reported that ''[[Chronicle (film)|Chronicle]]'' director [[Josh Trank]] would be directing the film adaptation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2012/05/23/chronicle-director-to-make-shadow-of-the-colossus-movie|title=Chronicle Director to Make Shadow of The Colossus Movie|date=May 23, 2012|author=Vejvoda, Jim|work=[[ign.com]]|publisher=IGN Entertainment, Inc|accessdate=May 24, 2012}}</ref> [[Seth Lochhead]] was due to write the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/hanna-writer-pen-shadow-colossus-409585|title='Hanna' Writer to Pen 'Shadow of Colossus' for Sony (Exclusive)|author=Borys Kit|work=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> In September 2014, Variety reported that ''[[Mama (2013 film)|Mama]]'' director [[Andrés Muschietti]] would direct the film after Trank dropped out due to his commitment to one of the upcoming ''[[Star Wars]]'' spin-off movies.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/andres-muschietti-to-direct-shadow-of-the-colossus-for-sony-1201297802/#|title=Andrés Muschietti to Direct ‘Shadow of the Colossus’ Adaptation for Sony|date=September 4, 2014|author=Kroll, Justin|publisher=Variety|accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heyuguys.com/mama-director-andres-muschietti-helm-video-game-adaptation-shadow-colossus/|title=Mama Director Andrés Muschietti to Helm Video Game Adaptation Shadow of the Colossus|date=September 4, 2014|author=Wilding, Josh|publisher=HeyUGuys|accessdate=September 4, 2014}}</ref>
== References == {{notelist}} {{Reflist}}
